reviewText:
At first glance, I Am Alive showed a lot of promise. The post apocalyptic atmosphere is believable. The story feels genuine. But ultimately playing it felt more like a chore than entertainment. The game concepts sound great on paper, but fall short on execution. It tries to pretend it's open world, yet is completely linear. I tried to play as a passive person, purposely trying to save lives and ammo, but nothing I did or didn't do mattered. Just about everyone I encountered had to die because they were the aggressor and wouldn't step down. There was no way to talk my way out of any situation. And if I pointed my gun at someone without the intention of using it, they always attacked as soon as I lowered my weapon or tried to walk away. Killing people became routine and expected so eventually I just started shooting first.

Then there's the stamina aspect which works well most of the time, until you unwittingly find yourself lost with no stamina to get back to safety, being forced to restart a level. And finally there's that genuine story which turns out to be nothing more than a dead end serving no purpose other than to keep the game moving forward. There is no closure here.

Attaching the Ubisoft name to this title feels very similar to attaching the Gearbox name to Aliens: Colonial Marines--setting up high expectations, only to be disappointed.

reviewText:
Mixed reviews for this game confuse me, it deserves better. Don't get me wrong though, many things people complain about are true and the game really is relatively short (around 4 to 5 hours of gameplay) and abrupt, however it offers a very unique combat system and the overall atmosphere is pretty good.

Playing on hard difficulty you will be forced into hard resource managment (mainly ammo management, also water and other stuff), therefore you can't just wander anywhere you want neither can you shoot everything that moves, you have to force your enemies to surrender by threatening them into surrender with your (often times not even loaded) gun. I loved the concept and look forward to other games implementing it. The second most important aspect of the game is post-apocalyptic atmosphere, as mentioned above it is executed fairly well and the game feels somewhat unusual and therefore interesting.

Surely, the game has it's flaws, they are mentioned in other reviews, However, I feel like most of them were brought up by people over-hyped by the game and therefore expecting it to be more than it actually can be. Some cons of the game I can think of is it's repetetiveness. Combat got somewhat repetetive but I am fine with that, what really annoyed me is climbing buildings over and over again (which was fun at first... but you can only climb so much without getting sick of it). And that's basically it, nothing else really stroke me during my first playthrough.

To sum up, I can recommend this game. Get it if it's on sale and you are looking for something post-apocalyptic with survival aspects and unusual combat system. Just don't put your expectations for it too high and you will enjoy it as long as you keep all those bad reviews off your mind while playing.

reviewText:
I'm a sucker for the post-apocalypse genre - the grittier, the better - and thus this game looked really promising. Unfortunately, I ended up being severely disappointed.

At first, the setting and mood was excellent, kinda like The Road (although thankfully not THAT harsh). I actually liked the stamina mechanism, too. In most games, your character is apparently a machine who can run/climb/fight/whine for hours without breaking a sweat, so such a nod to realism also got things started on the right foot. Graphics I didn't have much problem with, either. Hell, I grew up in the NES era, so I can forgive a lot on that score.

Unfortunately, I Am Alive went downhill pretty quickly from there. It's funny that I mentioned the NES, because this game actually reminded me of the old NES games... in all the worst ways.

It LOOKS like a GTA/Fallout-style open world at first, but looks are deceiving. I Am Alive is actually a linear game with constant barriers to keep you moving more or less along the one path. It's bitter that such an open-looking 3D world would offer so little room for exploration or experimentation.

Looking at the map for the first time (before I became aware of this game's true nature), I actually wondered which streets I should take to the apartment. I thought Okay
recommended: maybe less chance of being spotted by hostiles..." I soon learned that this game isn't big on exploration (or choices). That linear nature extended to the encounters

reviewText:
A rough hidden gem.

(I beat this game originally on the PS3)

Okay so it took Ubisoft: Shanghai 6 years to make the damn game and the age of it is immediately apparent.

When I first laid my eyes on the game I could not believe the sight - the graphics were so horrendous that I died a little inside. I went on to adjust brightness and contrast to no avail; I could barely see any difference or improvement. The anti-aliasing in this game is about -2x or -4x, that's right MINUS. The jaggies are all over the place. The water is a mess. The textures are also extremely dated. I can't take screenshots on my PS3 (I could if the game was on Steam thank you very much) so I started taking photos with my phone and sharing it with my friend. He could not believe it either. Call me a spoiled PC gamer but the graphics really killed off a portion of immersion for me right off the bat. The graphics are below average, I am sure most console gamers will agree with me.

However, one hour into the game and I was hooked. The civilization lays in ruins following a series of cataclysmic earthquakes and tsunamis; it's probably a pole shift. You arrive at the city in the search for your family with nothing but your back, some supplies, a flashlight and a camcorder (which is used for the cut scenes). Eventually get a machete, a gun, a shotgun and a bow. The game itself plays like a good survival movie. I've personally missed that genre for quite some time.

If you venture too far out into the dust-filled streets your stamina and health will slowly drain so you always have to make sure that you have enough supplies to replenish your stamina and health lest you suffocate and die. About that dust...It's been a year since the event and the dust still hasn't settled. So on one hand it's intriguing to not be able to see further than 6 feet away and struggle to get your bearings but on the other hand this trick can be viewed as a cop out on the part of the developers since they obviously haven't put much effort into graphics. The sound is good though. I played without the music. I liked the dead silence of the dead city.

You get to meet a total of 20 survivors in the game and help them out with supplies and other miscellaneous items so I advise you to save your supplies till the last and not use them until you meet someone who needs them. Helping every survivor will grant you an additional retry. This feature is helpful if you are playing on the survival mode which I heavily recommend for maximum immersion. Basically if you play on survival then you will be extremely cautions. And that's one of the biggest things that glued me to the game. It's that there is no trial and error here, you really have to think your moves ahead. I once got stranded on the other side of the mall and it took me my last two retries, most of my supplies and two pitons (used to rest while climbing) to find my way out. All in all, I spent about 30 minutes trying to find my way back in order to avoid starting the episode all over again.

I am actually surprised that the devs managed to make climbing interesting. Uncharted was probably the first game to do so but this game implements much more realism and puzzle solving when it comes to that. You can play as Nathan Drake, hang on the ledge and then go make yourself a veggie sandwich. By the time you come back Drake will still be here, hanging on a cliff above the abyss. That won't happen in this game. There is a small cliffhanger almost every time you climb somewhere. You have to make out the path in your head and figure out if you'll have enough stamina to climb to your destination. Your stamina will start draining, the ominous music will set it and your palms might start getting sweaty in real life.

As for the gameplay itself, well it delivers. When you aim you get the biggest, most ablest auto-aim I have ever seen in a video game. When you face the enemies you either have the choice of running, facing them head on, fooling them by attempting to do a surprise kill or subduing them by killing the leader of the gang. It's kind of like a checkers game. If you kill that one, then the two will rush you, if you kill that one then maybe you'll survive. If you try to rush the guy who has a gun with your machete then you will die. There are also a couple of stealth kills in the game. I have also exploited this trick to have the enemy AI shoot one of their own accidentally if you align yourself correctly. It worked every time and I saved myself health and ammo. About that ammo, yeah, the most bullets I was able to muster at one time in the game was 7 bullets.

A few more things that hampered the immersion for me. You don't talk back to the survivors, ever, you just stand there and listen. The bodies of the slain enemies disappear unfortunately. Some food items mysteriously reappear in some locations. Many AI (a guy with harry potter glasses) reappear in the game. For a total of 50 something enemies they could easily made more AI models. You can also kill some peaceful civilians without any repercussions. Upon their imminent death they will likely curse you for taking their life when they meant you no harm. At one point in the game you may actually kill a kid's parents by mistake. The story was okay and I liked the bleak melancholic ending.

All in all in took me 8 hours to beat the game.  The whole game takes place around only 4-6 square city blocks. The game also only occupies 2GB of hard drive space. Ubisoft could have really turned this into a franchise. They could easily make a sequel or a prequel but I guess it's not on their priority list.

reviewText: I had really high hopes for this game. Before it came out, I remember seeing all kinds of press for it, screenshots of vast urban decay, hints of in-depth exploration, all the features that make a post-apocalypse fan salivate. Yet the hype for it died completely off after release, and I actually completely forgot it existed until I saw it on a Steam sale. I finally decided to pick it up and play it. Right from the start there were multiple things that bothered me. The game doesn't seem to want to go too far in any direction no matter what the choice is, and that makes it overall very bland right from the get-go. The game is incredibly linear, guiding you in a single direction and not letting you veer off the course, yet they have tiny outlets from your linear path where you can find consumable items and whatnot. It's not rewarding to get these though. There was virtually no effort put into finding it aside from ♥♥♥♥ing off somewhere that wasn't the objective and after a short 5 second walk it's sitting on the ground for you. Why didn't they have the ability to search for supplies? checking dumpsters, containers, or piles of debris would have added so much more to this than simply walking slightly left of where you were originally going to go. The interactions with the AI are just as linear as the exploration. There are two types of people in the game, the I'm just trying to survive

reviewText:
I Am Alive was the very reason I started using the screenshot taking feature Steam offers. Probably most of the pictures I took were uploaded for this game only. I am still perplexed why people call this game ugly. It's environment is simply gorgeous. I look at the big picture here not tiny details such as not near perfect antialiasing or the highest HD textures available in current generation video games. Simply the city our protagonist arrives to looks stunning and depressing and superb. This desolate city is characterised by grey and white colours due to the fog, dust and toxic waste present and the beams of the sun shining through the sky are the most beautiful I have ever seen in a video game. Those being more expert in this area will probably challenge me - I have found this game visually stunning, regardless. I took numerous pictures especially when you climb the skyscrapers - those sequences are outstanding.

Gameplay-wise I Am Alive is a rather difficult TPS game. Even a single enemy can easily kill you. You have melee weapons at your disposal and any firearms you have provide you only with limited ammo. You need to plan every single encounter very carefully. The only letdown when it comes to this game its shortness. It can be completed in 5 or 6 hours with all side missions completed and collectibles obtained. Still, it is forgivable considering the budget was rather low for this one and also it's easy to catch this gem at a discounted price.

reviewText:
I Am Alive gives players a pure survival experience at a low price.
It is a short game, easily completed in 6 hours or so if you run through it.
The reason Im at 9 hours is simply because I wanted to explore more of the world and do some little side quests that there is very little reward for.

However, dont be fooled, this is a beautiful game

I Am Alive thrusts you into the role of a lone survivor in a believable, dark and insecure post-apocalyptic world. One year after the Event, a worldwide cataclysmic event that wiped most of the human race, a man struggles for survival in a desolate city as he tries to reunite with his long lost wife and daughter.

Pros
+ I Am Alive is brutal; gripping; captivating; depressing; miserable; and almost always utterly brilliant.
+ Storytale & development of both character and storyline is amazing
+ Emotional rollercoaster

Cons
- Linear game
- Short
- A game without a concluded ending

reviewText:
Although there are some flaws, the game is extremelly enjoyable, and as its price is very low now, it is a good catch.
Pros:
The designers created a truly horrific atmosphere: the game has scenes of sexual abuse, cannibalism and bleak morality, alhtough none of them are gratuitous
Good design: the game uses brutality to inform its simple mechanics.
You have to scale buildings, using windowsills and drainpipes for handholds, to achieve your objectives, and all those actions are tense because of your limited stamina - if your stamina reaches zero, you will fall to your death. So, the game forces you to use your resources at the right time or you will fail.
The game's setting – an American city, with all its skyscrapers cracked and its streets empty save for abandoned, rusting roadblocks.
Combat is tense too. Your char will always be short of ammunition, but will be facing large groups of enemies. Because of this setup, you will be forced to use surprise and your environment to survive. (as an example, in one of the encounter one of the best solutions is to slice the throat of the first person to get too close, then pull a gun on the remaining bandits and force them to back up against a ledge before kicking them to their deaths).
The bow and its two arrows (believe me, this one deserves the praise - you will be using it a lot)

Cons:
Because you face so many enemies from middle to the end of the game, you will end up repeating the same encounter many times, always following the same routine: surprise kill, shoot, ledge kick, etc.
The climbing, while tense, can become a grind, specially in the beginning of the game.
The ending: it seems the game was finished midway of its story. So, the main reason of the character going all the hardships will not be answered.

reviewText:
I Am Alive is actually a very refreshing and entertaining game.

- Through the dusty city in fictional city Haverton in America, there was a backstory known as 'The Event', that apparently was a bunch of earthquakes, though the backstory of post-apocalyptic essentially is present. The story is a series of events that occur in Haverton, which I must admit use a variety of buildings and adventures in order to fulfill the objectives, refreshing. The overall story is powerful through emotionally engaging with characters, for example, Mei and her mother. The story does tend to rush at the end as that could have been spaced out, though I will admit the ending is very strong and I was completely shocked by the ending. Oh, its a cliffhanger too.

- The graphics are beautiful in the game. For a 2012 game, they are at a high standard for that point in time. Speaking of Ubisoft, in 2012 they had a high standard of graphics in each game they released, which was their year in relation to graphics. The atmosphere and environment and the day/night dynamic is excellent graphically, though there could be some more day/night variations.

- The gameplay is solid. I do like the motions of the character and how he engages with the environment, which I felt was again for a lack of better word, refreshing, though different to other post-apocalyptic games. These same motions however, could be expanded a lot more. For example, if your character is on the ground, your stamina will deplete due to heavy dust that will affect it and eventually your health. The character walks basically like he is having a stroll as if there was minimal dust. To combat this, more diversity in actually producing motions when in the heavy dust could add a further dynamic to the gameplay. Stamina added a new dynamic to the game, which I appreciated. I liked the fact that this element suggested planning more so you as a player wouldn't deplete your stamina as fast as if you just went out there, so it was nice. I did love the element of preserving your bullets, as they could come in at handy times. There are a limited number of bullets in the game, and you do need them, though thats why planning is essential.

Regarding crooks and other gang members, I loved that element in the game, though it did get repeatitive as it was too basic. So everytime you walked up to a crook, you would have to kill him essentially, no reasoning, nothing, just plain old re-shooting the guy, whilst good, repeatitive. The camera control is an absolute pain. For example, whilst on a cliff and you look at the scenery and attempt to plan what portions of the building you have to climb, the camera will literally screw you up by making you deplete stamina because the camera was not facing the direction your player was moving at.

- There were bugs regarding graphics and gameplay that could have been ironed out, and balancing regarding camera control would have been appreciated. It didn't overly affect the game, but it was noticeable. Not as bad as some games I'll mention. Here are my pros/cons based off this review...

Pros:
- Strong story and backstory.
- Beautiful graphics.
- Day/Night dynamic, Atmosphere, and Environment are very good.
- Solid gameplay.
- Lovely balance overall.

Cons:
- Rushed ending to story.
- Day/Night could have been used more to enhance particular missions, apparently according to the main character near the end, the entire sequence of events happened in a day...
- Vague, but gameplay could be expanded upon.
- Bugs.


Overall, I Am Alive is a good game. It has its positives and negatives, however it has a very good foundation to build upon. The gameplay was solid, though it was basic for this genre and could have been more diverse to enhance the game. The story was strong, and the graphics were great. I do recommend this game at $17.99, however it is you, the readers, choice because I played this game on easy mode (there are 3 or 4 levels of difficulty) and it took me 8 hours to complete the game. So expect at least 10+ hours if you do the side-quests as well, as in help the surviviors. I did this partially (7/20). Score: 7.5/10

EDIT: I forgot to mention, dialogue is excellent in the game. Every set of people, be it main characters or thugs had dispirate dialogue, enhancing the game. I loved that aspect. Since I forgot to mention that, I'll bump my score from 7.25-7.5/10.

EDIT 2: This game lets you run your mind run wild on what happened to Haverton, what happened at the ending. It leaves a lot of aspects open for interpretation which works for this game. I forgot to mention, this game sometimes can feel like a chore to play, but personally that is what happened to me when I raged that I kept dying in the dust :p

----

Thanks for reading my review! If you like my reviews and care to read more, feel free to join Antwog's Analysis (Reviews). http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AntwogReviews

If you have questions comment below or post in Antwog's Analysis (Reviews) general discussion page. If you liked it, give it a rating.

reviewText:
Terribly disappointing. Really, really disappointing.

There are some games that, when I see them, I get hooked and tend to ignore most bad reviews. Sometimes, that is a wise choice, as I have found MANY games that I've loved that had terrible reviews all around. But other times, that is a terrible move, as the reviews are true.

In this case, the bad reviews are true. I am Alive is, well, terrible.

I was hooked since the first trailer ever released, and I never played it until now. Now, I wish I hadn't. I didn't want to just drop the game, as I hate doing that, so I just tried to play through as quickly as possible, ignoring the in-game achievements. Thankfully there are no Steam achievements, as I would hate to see the partial completion in that.

Anyway, to the point: Don't buy this game. The controls are horrible. Getting a controller helps, but it's still wonky. The combat is no good. You can sneak attack someone, which is cool at first, but it wears off. Besides that, you can shoot people but ammo is TERRIBLY scarce. I understand that this game is survivalist, but your guy has been out there forever, and he begins the game with like a water bottle and that's it.

The only other way to fight is with your knife. If the combat was more action-oriented, then it would have been better. Instead, you're usually screwed when fighting gangs. Your only knife attack (besides the sneaking one to get the first edge-up) is to run up to someone's face and proceed into a button-mashing event while you're left open to all other baddies. Your guy can't just stab and slash in an active manner. Instead, he can only lock his knife with the other guy and sit there while being shot. And each time he's shot, the event has to be restarted.

Therefore, combat is terrible. It should have been more fluid and action-oriented.

And as for the climbing... God, such a pain. I liked what they were trying to do at first, but then got over it quickly. Again, it's a survivalist game, but it is just too much. You have a fatigue meter which, when you lose enough fatigue, also will lose its capacity. If you don't have items to restore capacity, you're screwed and usually find yourself in a vicious circle of needing to find items which require either (a) ammo to shoot a lock or (b) you to climb somewhere. But chances are you're looking for ammo already, or you're looking for an item to help you climb. So often you're forced to restart places or re-attempt entire sections.

And the graphics--they look like someone digitalized sawdust and filtered it through the imagery. The game can still look ugly and apocalyptic without looking... THAT kind of ugly.

There's more issues, as I found many glitches along the way, the story was lackluster, and on and on and on.

Overall, I was terribly disappointed. Do not play this game.

reviewText: I know there are a lot of critics raving about how much they hate this game, but I'm just gonna come out and say it: I love it. Even though the graphics aren't perfect, and the colour scheme is mildly bland, I love the gritty, dark and dusty feel to the game. The story line is bittersweet and I really liked the AI, because although some of the lines were cheap, the split second decision to draw/not draw your weapon, point an empty gun at someone (bullets are hard to come by) was somehow... pretty lifelike. I especially enjoyed the obstacle courses, with the added adrenaline of knowing that you only have a certain amount of stamina to perform tasks.\n\nI would definitely say, get it while it's on special... but do yourself a favour and get it :) you might just end up enjoying it too!

reviewText: In my opinion, this game missed out on so much. You're brought into a world/environment that could be rife with background and stories but somehow they manage to leave you (or me, at least) feeling both wanting to know more about it and also not caring about what is told about what happened. A lot fo the comments about whatever took place feel like a passing explanation - as if no thought has been put into it and just trying to brush it off.\nThe main character's story/search feels COMPLETELY dismissed for 95% of the game. I can understand being a character that wants to help people but when it comes to the point of getting home and not finding what you wanted, right there it seems to be thrown onto the backburner. reviewText:
I'm not really sure if I should recommend this game or not.
To me, This game was incredible in design and mechanics. The trailer versus the end result did leave me wanting though, I expected a bit, no, alot more.

This is an unfinished game to say the least, it won't take you more than a few hours to complete, and once you do, you don't feel like you did anything really, it's not an open world game, HAH! you wish.
The only hint you get as to what happens when this is all done, is that your character is 85% dead, and 15% Missing in action.
Not a good ending for an otherwise decent game. I just wish the game had an open world, and was a little more fleshed out, as well as having a dynamic day-and night cycle, but nope.

It's been a few years since this game came out, so let my in-game time speak for itself, i completely finished this games storyline.... Three times. sooooo, 23 divided with 3? That makes a little more than 7 hours per playthrough.
8 hours is the average minimum playsession For a person like me, take a guess how I felt after beating this game the same day I bought it. Not very pleased.


Now then, as for mechanics? there's alot of nice aspects here, but also alot of pit-falls. You'd think your character could climb stuff, right? Nope, only when it's an obvious spot. If you can't obviously see the spot to climb, you can't climb it. And even then, it doesn't feel natural.

E V E R Y T H I N G that happens in this game is scripted to happen, down to even the ''loot'' you can find, oh, and it doesn't appear to respawn either, if it does, i've been too quick doing the quests in this game, since there was literally nothing else to do.

combat is a pain in the ♥♥♥, that's all I can say. I can't really remember it well, but I don't think your character can swing his weapon at all, if he can, it's so slow that any enemy can just interrupt you. And ammo is so scarce, that you'll want to save it till the last part.

You are going to die ALOT int this game, and 75% of your deaths, are going to be cheap shots. with about half of those cheap shots being developer created pitfalls in the climbing areas in this game.


So, what can I say? I don't recommend this game, had it been longer, maybe. If they had made this an open world game, and added sidequests? Definitely.
But as it stands, I can't say yes to this game, not for this price, wait for it to go on sale. It's definitely something you'll want to try, but don't spend your hard earned cash expecting this to be a revelation of some sort. It's not.

reviewText:
I Am Alive... or Am I Dead?

Ok, game that was in development for a really long time. Heck it was announced at E3 2008 and the game had been shadowing the gaming industry for a long while; even having rumors of cancellation. Alas, it finally got out on consoles at first, then on PC in September 2012.

So what is this game? You play as some dude, returning to Havington, a year later after some EVENT" occured. No info about what the event is... So you head to that city to find your lost wife and daughter only to stumble upon an asian kid and her mother. Then you go around and try to keep them safe while fighting some other survivors that made gangs.

PROS:
-The setting is nice

hoursPlayed:
voice acting and even the graphics are decent.

CONS:

-Poor "retry mode" system that if you die and out of "retries"

only to find soda cans that replenish stamina.

Worth buying?

ONLY at discount! I Am Alive can provide you a good 5-7 hours of playtime... more if you seek to help every refugees.

RATING: 5 / 10

===SPOILER ALERT===

reviewText: First off despite its flaws I think I Am Alive is a pretty epic post apocalyptic survival experience unlike anything I've ever played before. For a budget game it has mostly exceeded my expectations by managing to perfectly encapsulate the scarcity of resources and that dusty, ruble-y ruined post apocalyptic world setting. Though my favorite aspect of the game would have to be the mind games you're forced to play with your enemies. Imagine having to shoot the biggest guy in the group with your bow in hopes of getting the smaller ones to surrender, then whipping out your handgun with 0 ammo in order to intimidate the remaining foes just so you can retrieve your only arrow from the corpse to kill off some more scavengers with it. Secondly its a console port with a weird ♥♥♥ control scheme, sure you can rebind the keys but its still felt pretty weird, I think its best played with a controller although you'll most likely be fine with kb/m and Thirdly I did not experience any performance issues with it at all, it ran at a constant 60fps all the way through, the only problem is that its locked at 60 even with vsync off and editing the config file did not unlock the buttery smooth 144hz experience.\n\nnoUplayFTW /10

reviewText:
Ugh, this game falls short in so many ways.  Within the first minute of playing, I could tell right off the bat that whoever designed the camera had NO idea what they were doing.  It's god awful.

So what's to say?  All gray palette with no color, terribly linear game mechanics in a world I thought would reward exploration when risk was involved.  No ability whatsoever to converse or negotiate with other survivors so it's usually walk away from a hoarder or kill every bandit.

The necessity to kill every bandit you encounter is ironic, considering the game rewards you when you help people in need of aid.  I rage quit when I was facing three  bandits with machetes and only had one bullet with absolutely no way to take care of the other two without getting my ♥♥♥ beat.

Interesting idea but overall, it fails quickly.

reviewText:
I Am Alive was a really good Xbox arcade game, with a subpar PC port that costs way too much after 4 years.

Graphically this game is beautiful, but at the same time is almost a direct port from console with no extra effort put in to make it look better on PC, meaning it lacks the full gamut of options a game intended for PC would have. The desaturated color pallette common to movies and games that share similar themes like Fallout, The Road, Rage, Book of Eli, Mad Max and other post apocalyptic media fits the game perfectly. Unfortunately, it also garnered the game a lot of negative attention from whining casuals who only see overall trends in gaming and don't judge games based on their merits.

I Am Alive is the story of a guy who was away from home when weather disasters destroyed the world [ostensibly] and has spent every moment since trying to get back to his wife and daughter. The game combines recognizable platforming with beautiful post-civilization landscapes, but also features melee and gun combat more akin to a realistic survival game (at least until the latter part of the game where you get a lot of ammo). Ammo is scarce and healing items more scarce. Everyone you encounter is an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ trying to kill you, and even some of the people you try to rescue will try to trick you into being killed like a lot of random NPCs in Witcher 3 or GTA5 will do.

The story is predictable, and I'm not sure if the title of the game is supposed to be ironic or not, but I wish that the Chinese sect of Ubisoft that developed this were working on a full fledged sequel or re-imagining. Really the negative aspects of this game are the low fidelity graphics and the awful controller support on PC - not to mention the obvious lack of Steamworks integration for things like achievements.  I really wish the controller mapping was functional, because it makes this game all but unplayable on computer.

If you can look past that or use something like Controller Companion, this game is worth the time of anyone who likes platformers or post-civilization games.

reviewText:
First thing's first - don't let the mixed reviews scare you off.

I guess detrimental to its success was the fact that this game came out way before the whole survival/resource-management shtick came into fashion.

Despite what you may read, the game is pretty enjoyable. Granted, you shouldn't play the whole thing in one sitting. Also because it's fairly short. But considering it probably never was planned as one, nor was it given the budget to be a major release (and it shows), the end product turned out great imho.

The atmosphere and graphics are decent, the gameplay too. Yes, the camera rotation and player movement tend to hickup every now and then, but not in a 'deal-breaker' way.

Another thing I thoroughly enjoyed was that there wasn't 'one correct way' to get from A to B. Sure, when it came to getting from one quest location to another, the game is pretty linear, but at the locations themselves you can get into dead ends, so this will force the player to really think their actions through. Which is refreshing.
It is also refreshing, because the game WILL punish you if you are careless. Or reckless.
And it is very thorough in doing so.
Forget saving at will. You get checkpoints. And you get limited retry tokens. Stamina depleting during climbing also makes you reconsider the routes you take.  None of that willy-nilly climbey monkey BS in Assassin's Creed. :P
Bullets? Limited. Arrows? Better strategize, because you need to draw it first and that gives your foes plenty of time to run up and butcher you.

The only thing I didn't really like was the lack of closure in the storyline. I mean, not to divulge any spoilers, but it really leaves the player thinking like it ended too soon. Like there's a chunk of the story we didn't get to see/play/experience. And that is a pity. Yet Ubisoft has obviously it's priorities and funds elsewhere.


Oh, and before I forget - best part? It DOESN'T use uplay.


TL;DR - MEAN every bullet, LOOK before you climb, micromanage to survive.

7 decent hours of fun if you're into survival sims.

reviewText:
I was really impressed by this game. It's immense atomsphere of post-apocalyptic city with no usual zombies aboard just made me forget about all the weak spots (and there are lots of them). Really deep immersion into the setting. You feel alone, scared and depressed all the time. As I already mentioned there are no zombies or aliens or any other fictional stuff. It is a sad grey quest through desolated concrete jungle filled with murderers, rapists and few normal people who are mostly busy with... well, dying. Some gameplay mechanics (such as stamina loss when climbing or suffocating on the bottom levels covered with dust) came out to be very good ideas for making the game closer to real life. Lack of supplies makes it more challenging - you won't be running around with pockets full of different types of ammo and various goods.

However, if we speak about the tech part, I Am Alive is far from perfect. I would say that the graphics are very avearge for a product of 2012. It feels more like a game of 2008. The makers did pretty bad job for a product that has been in development for like 5 or 6 years. Sometimes it felt like the they didn't put much effort in this title (especially when everyone were waiting for The Last of Us which came out a year later).

Anyway, I do recommend this game for anyone who likes post-apocalyptic settings. It has a unique atmosphere and is definitely worth trying.

reviewText: I Am Alive might have been a great game but it manages to fall over itself in several critical categories. The first is atrociously awful combat, where you are saddled with an avatar who has only two combat moves and both are ridiculously hobbled. The first is shooting a gun, which is effective in dealing with enemies but ammunition is purposely in extremely short supply. The second is melee combat, but the only move you can make is to grapple with an enemy and jab a knife into their midsection, and that move can be interrupted by getting hit. Essentially this means you are helpless against groups, because you won't have enough ammunition to take down all the enemies and melee is impossible against more than one person. Of course, the game frequently throws you against groups. Toss in a hobbled save-game system (save-points, and only a handful of retries before you have to restart the entire level) and combat becomes a game-killer.\n\nThe platforming, the other half of the game, is too cumbersome and limited to make exploration enjoyable, and the dreary, limited graphics mean you won't want to wander the world anyway. The game does open up some after a while, becoming far less linear than its first few levels make it appear, but there's really not that much to do in the world so there's no point. And just when you think you are starting to make progress, the game suddenly ends, with no resolution or even a climax. It's a disappointing game on so many levels.

reviewText:
So, I'm gonna make this one short. I really enjoyed I AM ALIVE but once you look at the game on the paper it pretty much sucks.

On the plus side we have:
+Fun.
+Good Story.
+A decent morality system that I will talk about in a second.
+The difficulty is nothing crazy but satisfying.
+SOME good character dialog.

On the other hand we have:
-The awful Graphics.
-The bad combat system.
-The game took me around 5 hours to complete and I also did most of the side missions.
-Minor bugs(nothing too bad)
-That annoying dust filter in sequences where you are outside of the dust.

The (kind of) morality system:
Now there isn't much of a real morality system other than a few things like don't steal"
date: don't eat humans". Those things will give a small boost to your endscore. However I found myself thinking about my victims as you will often find yourself in a place where YOU raid a camp. I only killed 3 innocents while playing and every time there was a way around them

I had a lot of fun with this game and it didn't frustrate me at all

reviewText:
Terrible. Awful.

The graphics are grainy, dark and washed-out. The controls are awkward. The fighting sequences are rote-learnt and lack any variation or subtlety. The platform puzzles fail to entertain.

The world is tiny. Just a few city blocks in total. You don't even need to visit more than half the map to complete the main quest. If you try to explore the map the game forces the camera around and chastises you for going in the wrong direction. The linearity of this game is so frustrating. I can see the world, let me explore it!

The unsatisfying ending is both ham-fisted and obvious.

You can tell the developers had a bigger vision. There are random NPCs scattered throughout the world, suggesting sub-quests were once on the table. The world design suggests an open-world sandbox exploration game was intended. But their vision was never delivered. The story has been castrated. The mechanics have been lobotomised. The world has been decimated.

The game is a mess. Don't waste your time or money on this rubbish.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: While I can't speak for the quality of this game on a console, I suppose a review of that would be irrevelant since this is on PC. This is an absolutely terrible port of the game. The control scheme, while interesting, was not ideal. Not unplayable, but not easy to get used to. The gameplay itself was ok, but the movement and the action was the worst part. I had huge difficulty getting through one of the first fight scenes. I can't say whether this was from the difficulty curve being too steep, or the controls not functioning properly, or just simply the game mechanics being terrible, but whatever the reason, it wasn't enjoyable. To touch briefly on the movement, it goes along with the controls being bad. Again, I'm sure if I had played more, I would've gotten used to the button mapping, but I've played a lot of games with a lot of different control scemes, and this was by far the most unique. To use mouse 1 to sprint, and to repeatedly tap it to run faster is unheard of. I'm aware that I could remap the buttons, but I shouldn't have to remap almost every button. Overall, the game was just not impressive, and frankly, not very playable. If you're are a very forgiving and lenient gamer, then you may enjoy this game, but I simply could not overlook the broken mechanics. Perhaps on a different console, it would be more enjoyable. 3/10.

reviewText:
Without giving anything away, let me just say that I Am Alive is incredibly depressing. I'm not talking about the story, which is half baked and clearly cuts off well before whatever script the developers were working off of ended. I'm talking about the fact that every single moment of the game was spent remembering how excited I was after the first trailer came out, promising an open world exploration that never ended.

Instead, the final product was this ♥♥♥♥. The game gets repetitive after the first level, and nothing actually happens. There is no open world, just some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ unfulfilling side missions that were clearly tacked on in a desperate attempt to make the game seem deep.

I do like the almost but not quite monochrome stylings of the graphics, they addded a nice touch to the ambiguously post-apocalyptic wasteland that I barely got to properly explore.

At some point it became necessary for the player character, whose name I already forgot, to lash a young girl to his backpack and ♥♥♥♥ around sheer walls for a while. This was very annoying...
To repeat my previous point, I am Alive was originally meant to be a massive adventure through a broken world, like S.T.A.L.K.E.R. with platforming elements.
The last thing I need is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ plot device hooked to my character, constantly reminding me of how good this game would have been if it hadn't hit so many problems during development.

The main character dies at the end, you don't find out why. Presumably, somewhere between the end of the game and the credits, he went on aforementioned huge exciting journey without the player.

Don't buy this game. Ubisoft needs to go back and try making this game a second time, perhaps actually making the game they said they were making the first time around.

reviewText: I will start this by stating that it's a decent game.  I found it to be extremely easy, but it's a decent game nonetheless.  However, these are some key issue that I would like to point out.  The main issue is that there is almost no back story.  I know, people will think 'but there has to be, even a little.'  Well, there is a little, but it is only learned through playing the early stages.  Other than that, however, there is no general narrative that sums up the state of the world at or before the time of the game.  Now, this isn't to say it's a horrible game.  It is interesting, but it's more like a demo of plausible video game features, rather than an actual game.  I would also say that it's fairly short.  Even when you are trying to achieve all of the in-game mini quests, it's still short.\n\nUnless it's on sale, I do not recommend purchase.  4/10

reviewText:
I've clicked yes to recommend this game but please note that I do so only as I enjoyed the storyline. I defiitely do not recommend this game if you are not buying it at a discounted price. I completed it in 6 hours.

Atmospherically the game is great. For those of you who enjoy post-apocalypse games, you will enjoy this. The storyline is good and gritty.

On the bad side, interaction i the game is kept to a minimum. If you are a big fan of Fallout and want something to tide you over until number 4 is out, this will barely scratch that itch. All interaction with survivors is limited to one single button push to determine if you help them or if you don't. Combat is equally simplified and extremely repetetive.

I enjoyed the game. I'm glad I played it. Now that I have finished it however, I will delete it as I have no intention of ever playing it again as it is completely linear.

reviewText:
Lets start with the good things as there are few.
1. The levels itself - are in itself atmospheric, it really gives you the impression how a town could look like after a series of earthquakes.
2. The climbing mechanic - that you loose endurance/stamina if you climb is a nice change.
3. Overall interesting take on survival in a town after a global catastrophic event - without the obligatory zombies.

Yeah...that's it.

Now to go on with the bad things where do I start:
The graphics are washed up and even if you use the highest settings you can't change the fact that this piece of crap was meant to be played on an XBOX or PS2. Yes I know - it is developed for the XBOX 360 and PS3 but I can't drop the feeling that I have seen better graphics in part on a XBOX or PS2.
The music at the beginning is good and adds to the little bit of atmosphere there is at all - but it gets so repetitive after a time (especially as you loose stamina constantly and with you loosing stamina the music builds up and always the same tune) that you sometimes just want to mute the whole game.
So now we know that the game itself is just a common stone between pearls and diamonds in terms of audio and graphics, but there are these rare jewels that suck at this too but still have great gameplay and story.
This game is absolutely NOT one of them.
The gameplay is overall horrific with the exception of the climbing mechanic.
Combat or stealth - it gives you no choice - you have to fight.
There is no sneaking (although they implemeted the sneak button how cool is that) at all, the moment you pass a certain point the game spawns enemies and you can not get around them either because they detect you on the spot or you desperately try to get by the ones that are already somewhere in the level - and the level is created so that you have to get through them.
This is no THIEF" at all.
So lets "fight" which comes down to coerce the AI in getting stuck or other "special" movements.
Why?
Because you either have guns - for which you practically never have any ammunition or you can use your mighty machete.
Nonono
recommended: you have to wait until your enemies have reached you and then you can draw your machete for one hit.\nIf it is someone with a machete he will block it and you have to go through button smashing
hoursPlayed: it is easier if the enemy has a gun
voteText: then no button smashing.\nThe only problem is that these guys come in packs.\nSo the moment you have to buttonsmash and are locked in the scripted killscene
helpfulPercent: our enemies friends are hacking you to pieces OR his gun equipped buddies just kill you with one shot (ok
votesHelpful: ok @ higher difficulty)\nThe AI can shoot at you forever but if you loot them they magically have emptied everything they had after 1001 shots (one of the many bugs in this game shows you that fact when you get stuck somewhere in a wall and they use you as invincible target practice or you just run around eating up your health items just to see how often they can fire) if you are lucky there is one bullet left after you killed them
votesTotal:
about 50% of the time the gun is empty although the owner of it WILL kill you with it if you believe that you could reload the level and just walk past by him.
Yes I have the feeling that the people working at this game desperately wanted to shoot themeselves after they saw what they had created and implemented this thoughtful underlying message of the last bullet.
You can get a shotgun in the game but first you really have to do some climbing and exploring and the few shots you have are the only ones in the whole game.
After around 75% of the game you get a bow with one arrow - oh and you won't believe it - YES!! you can reuse that arrow.

The story is pretty mediocre
votesFunny:
you should have encountered it somewhere else already and probably better told but worst of all it is pretty shortlived (around 8 hours and I took my sweet time) and cut at the end.
The ending is one bad joke.
I couldn't help but think that at some point of production they really believed they had born a new superloved AAA title hence the dream of producing dlcs and a second game.
But when at the end they realized what a boring abomination they helped to bring into this gamingworld they just hurried up and forced some kind of ending in and a really bad one too.
The bottom line is that if you really want to try out this game buy it in a Steam Sale...for up to 3 $/€.
Anything more will make you wish you had tossed that money in a blender and watched it blend - more entertainment for the buck."

reviewText:
This game took a couple of hours to really get used to.  The story is essentially about a man working his way back to his family after a catastrophe.  The colors are really, super bland (expected, I guess for the setting), but what took the most getting used to were the controls, they felt delayed (maybe it was me?).

I did enjoy some of the platforming-ish type puzzles to solve.  Because of the rarity of ammo, weapon combat could get intense and I never really got the hang of melee.  The dust mechanic was kind of cool (loss of stamina until you reached fresh air), but it wasnt enough to hook me.

I suppose my whole feelings on the game could be summed up with this statement, I spent more time wishing for it to end than was spent enjoying it.""

reviewText:
First off, I would like to state that I have yet to complete this game out of sheer frustration.
Though I will keep on attempting to finish the game,
granted if I can win the race between me finishing the game and my controller breaking.
That being said, here are my two cents about this game.

I will start off with the bad side of the game in order to create a critique that feels like you are eating a pudding with glazed sugar layered at the bottom, where the further you go and eat in more of the chunks, the sweeter it gets.

I Am Alive was once an extremely anticipated game when it was first leaked on 2009, and announced to be completed on 2010, but was later pushed back several times before finally being released on 2012. This gave potential buyers the time to ponder about the game.

When news first befell unto my ears, I heard so many rumors that this game would become the ultimate open world survival game with a good storyline to follow through. However, like any fairly hyped games, you are bound to be disappointed.
The final product released into the market looked like a stillbirth compared to what people were expecting from the game.
As a result, the game's popularity sank faster than a fat lady trying to water skii whilst wearing lead shoes.
Granted, this is not entirely the developers' fault, as speculations may have created greater expectation, but could be easily diminished by not being so hush about the game's situation and deliver actual information and updates rather than popping up ever so often just to deliver push-backs.

Over the course of some five hours of me playing this game, I can sum up the game in three words, Trial and error."
By using new players' naiveté

column61:
all over it, as this was mentioned to be a trial and error game with limited tries.
As for its staticity, every event and item placement are always at exactly the same place, even with static events, you would at least expect non-static placements for loots, and hope that perhaps that one time when you recheck that mundane corner again, a flashing item surrounded by an white aura would appear, like a young kid hoping to find Narnia in their grandmother's wardrobe, only to find an abundent amount of mothballs located within.

Oh, and the save system sucks harder than an industrial grade vacuum cleaner.

Despite so many factors, including the menu being complete and utter stinking fecal matter, that make this game so frustrating, I cannot get myself to hate this game.

All in all, I am just so very intrigued by the world, the environment, and the idea of this game.
Despite the frustration I Am Alive makes me deal with, during the immersive moments of the game, when I truly looked, especially into the story and the world, this game makes me feel in awe, and delivers so many other emotional impacts, like a pyromaniac seeing a forest on fire for the first time (to which the aforementioned person may or may not have been the cause of).
I realize that I am on my own in the broken world.

I realize that this game is not be for everyone, hence I would not recommend this game.
However, if you are willing to overlook the many flaws I have already pointed out, and the ones I may have forgotten about, go ahead and try it out, but I do not in any way guarentee a frustration-free playthrough.

TL;DR:
You most likely will not like it, but if you are willing to look at the game in a different perspective, by all means, go for it.

reviewText: The gameplay is fantastic. The freerunning aspects are relatively realistic and fun. The fast paced tactical decisions in combat are difficult to get used to but rewarding when you beat them after about the fifth reload, assuming you don't mind retrys being a significant portion of your playtime. That said, the game uses a horrible retry system where you find the right to reload a save like a power up, and if you run out, it sends you to the begining of the level.  Had an amazing amount of potential, but appeared painfully unfinished. I tore through most of the game in four hours, then spent most of the next day looking forward to finishing it. When I did, there was only about 20 minutes of content left and I was left without closeure to the story and a lot of massive disappointment.    When the game ended it even presented me with a stat board full of trackings of things that were never even an option in the playthrough.\n\nThe game is clearly an abandoned project and in its current state is too short to be worth getting into.

reviewText:
This game has a lot of flaws, but it still manages to create a unique experience unlike anything you've ever played.
Unlike most post-apocalyptic games, you don't have any zombies or monsters to fight. Your biggest enemies are the environment, the lack of resources and the other survivors.
Getting places is hard. Roads are blocked and bridges are broken, and your climbing skills are the only thing keeping you alive. Problem is, you have a very limited amount of stamina that drains every time you climb or run, and when it's drained fully - you fall. As if that's not enough, dust storms make the air outside unbreathable, and when inside the fog your stamina will constantly drain until you die, or reach high ground.
Resources are very limited, and you will rarely have more than 2-3 bullets in your gun. You will often have none. Combat is not based on who shoots faster, but on psychology and bluffing. Raise your hands to let the enemy come near enough for a surprise attack, or aim your empty pistol at him and tell him to back off up to a cliff, then push him over.
This combat system makes you get very creative when fighting 5-6 enemies, since you probably wont have enough bullets to kill them all.
Some survivors will only fight you if you get too close, and backing off will prevent a fight. Others will ask for your help, and you will have to choose wether or not to spare your very limited supplies.
With this combat system and the constant pressure of the draining stamina, this game keeps you stressed throughout it all. And as if that's not enough - you have a limited number of retries before having to restart from the beginning of the chapter!

The game is flawed, though:
Controls can be a bit clunky while climbing, sometimes resulting in a pointless death and waste of retry.
It's not always clear where to go, especially in heavy dust where you can't see ♥♥♥♥, and you might end up walking in circles trying to find the entrance to a building, and it can get quite frustrating.
The story is very lacking. You learn pracitcally nothing about what actually happened and the story just seems to stop rather than end when you finish the game.
While the game is semi-openworld, you have little to no motivation to explore. Yeah, you might find other survivors or some food and water, but is it really worth running around in a dust storm for?

Overall, this game is a solid 8/10 and I highly recommend playing it.

reviewText: I still like this game. I like the gameplay, the graphics, the ambience and the environment. I like the story it tells. This atmosphere of catastrophe reminds me of real natural disasters. The ruined city drowned in thick dust fog, abandoned properties became miserable, and blazing sun turned unbearable. Besides the game shows how much humanity costs. It makes me think about it. It makes me love and appreciate my comfortable life. But the game has the only one flaw (for me, of course) - it's too short. And yes, I wish the story will have a sequel. I'd love to buy it.

reviewText:
Despite reading mixed reviews of this game I was surprised it was actually this good. The world has been struck by earthquakes and it's up to you, a survivor, to try and find your family.

The graphics are dark and moody; you can only see a few metres ahead which makes it difficult to differentiate friend from foe. It really adds to the tension. That, and the lack of bullets. You have to pick targets carefully, and even decide if you want to kill them. It's not always needed, you see, and you really need to preserve your ammo.

There are also other survivors to be found and they might need your help. It's up to you. Helping them will grant you a retry. So in the event that you are killed you'll be able to try it again.
Besides killing and helping people you'll be climbing around like the PoP and AC games, which feels natural by now, and is cool.

Too bad the game is a bit short; it will take most people around 4-6 hours to complete.

Yet another game that has to be experienced, people.

[Rating: 81/100]

reviewText:
If you're a fan of post-apocalyptic games then this is a must have. You play as a survivor of the apocalypse searching the forgotten city to find your family. This game shows quite a realistic view of what it would be like in an apocalypse with it's dark atmosphere, having to scavenge for food, ammo and survivors. I Am Alive is very similar to The Last of Us in many ways as they are both post-apocalyptic survival games.

The combat in I Am Alive has a more strategic approach as you have to take in the amount of ammo and health you have, also whether the enemies have a gun or a machete or even armour. Also what was awesome was how you're able to use the environment to kill an enemy, e.g. Holding your gun out to an enemy who has only but a machete and forcing him to walk back into a fire or off a cliff.

The overall gameplay gives you more of a restricted feel as you can't explore a lot of the areas and a lot is just blocked off. One thing that got my frustrated a lot was the camera view. Not being able to kill the right enemies due to slight knock of your mouse can really be frustrating. Another thing I didn't like was the amount of climbing you have to do as it just got repetitive and became a hassle.

The game only took about 4-4.5 hours to complete and so in conclusion, yes I'd highly recommend this game if it's on sale and you enjoy survival horror and post-apocalyptic games.

reviewText:
I found this game to be very enjoyable. I really liked the atmosphere, I thought the story was satisfying for a while but by the end I was left wanting just a little more, and I thought the environment was beautifully crafted. I do think this game could've used a little more color, though.

This isn't the best game around, but I like it. I think it's worth the price that it currently sells for. If you are in need of an interesting singleplayer game to play, try this one. I thought the intimidation" feature where you can scare off enemies by just pointing a gun at them even if its not loaded was pretty cool and original. Climbing in this game can be fun. This game is really just full of unique features that you won't find in most other games of the post-apocalyptic survival category.

Other notes: the graphics are just good; not excellent

reviewText:
Pros:
+ Atmosphere of abandonment, decline and hopelessness. Felt like LIMBO at times.
+ The character feels like a veteran post apocalyptic survivor.
+ Story is simple but believable.
+ Well built environment. The urban setting looks like it's gone through hell.
+ Loved the climbing which was one of the best features of the game.
+ Enemy encounters feel very realistic. You barely make it out alive.

Cons:
- There were problems with the climbing mechanics. I wish it would have felt smoother and not so rigid. Also keys would not register at times.
- Didn't really like the saving system, I would have enjoyed more control there.

Verdict:
It's a highly tactical post-apocalyptic survival game with a wonderful atmosphere. It's got a wonderful setting and some quite original features.

reviewText:
I Am Alive? More like I Am Alpha!

Because it's a clearly rushed product that's not very well optimized, is ugly, is short as hell and ends strangely and abruptly.

It's also one of the best B-games I've ever played.

I Am Alive drops you into a world torn asunder by a cataclysmic event. You're just a guy looking for people from his past, trying to help those in need, and trying to survive in a harsh reality where everything's out to get you. Your main ability is climbing, and the climbing system of IAA is really well-done: it controls a lot like Uncharted or Tomb Raider, but with the addition of a Stamina system: the longer you climb, the more your bar depletes. If it gets to the end, you'll still be able to climb, but your maximum stamina capacity will slowly dwindle until you get to a resting spot. You can restore your max stamina with items, but it's a neat take on providing urgency to a system that's been used before.

The combat is the second tier of the game, and it's also exceptionally well-done: the game utilizes an Intimidation system, which allows you to bluff your opponents using an empty gun while you try to control fights to your favor. Sometimes they'll call your bluff, and you'll have to either shoot them or go for a machete kill; other times, you might want to approach hostiles unarmed, wait for one to get close, and then attack with your machete, surprising everyone and giving you the upper hand. Ammo is scarce, and you don't want to waste a bullet: chances are if you miss a shot, you're about to die. The guns feel good, and the fact that unarmored foes die in one hit is an absolutely incredible way of finally adding realistic gunplay, which makes every encounter memorable. If you come across guys with guns, you either need to be unarmed and hope they come to search you or shoot them first. You will probably die a few times before you get the hang of things, and enemies flanking you might surprise you.
You later get a bow, which leads to interesting combat encounters since arrows are recoverable and the bow is silent.

The story, largely, is told by victims you save and the few friendly people you encounter on your journey and is well-written. The dynamic you have with the first friendly character you meet is the best, leading you to develop an emotional attachment to them. It's not going to win any awards, but it certainly helps to keep you motivated.

The game's not without its flaws, however; the ending is rushed, unsatisfying, and leaves you with a lot of questions, and there are times when the checkpoint system can get very annoying. I played the game on Normal and it was pretty tough, but I never had to restart a chapter. There are segments where you wander aimlessly through the streets, hoping to find something climbable to either save you from the dust storms or lead you to the next destination. The game is also (not, in my eyes, a negative) very short (I clocked in at 4h059s) which could leave some people thinking they overpaid.

I really liked my time within I Am Alive's world, and a fully-developed sequel or spin-off in the same world would be more than welcome.
8/10 Bows and Bullets

reviewText:
Let's just start of by saying that I Am Alive is basically TLoU Lite (even though it came out much earlier). You're in a crapsack world, almost everyone is out to kill you, you take care of a little girl, go on platforming/climbing jaunts, and have a painfully limited supply of ammunition.

Where I Am Alive falls apart is the story. The skeleton of something that could be really good is in here, somewhere, and you catch glimpses of it during your (short) stay in Haventon. Unfortunately, the story is never quite brought to fruition. Protracted delays in development, budget cuts, and a final rushed release (as an XBLA release instead of a full retail) all likely contributed to what is IMO an unfinished game.

The game isn't bad per se, it just doesn't do anything particularly well. The platforming could definitely have been done better; the stamina system is interesting, but I found far too many regen items and pitons (which you can use to rest while climbing to regain stamina) to make it really worthwhile. In the end, the whole system seems like a hindrance to my enjoyment of the game, rather than a useful mechanic. Combat is fairly basic, and usually boils down to picking off the people with firearms first, and then pushing the others off of cliffs or stabbing them. The rush you get from your first few hold-ups fades pretty quickly when you realize that EVERY encounter is the same.

I would (possibly) have excused all of this had the story been more fleshed out. The ending seems absolutely shoe-horned in after the team ran out of funding.

I find it hard to recommend this game to anyone, given how poorly it ends.

reviewText:
IAA far exceeded my expectations. Its reception was lukewarm--often characterized by extreme and vocal loathing; it's a modern Ubisoft title; Stanislas Mettra said some very stupid things that got a lot of equally stupid reactions; &c.

It feels like the budget title it is, so gameplay mechanics are stiff and it often feels like a poor man's Uncharted set in a poor man's McCarthy-obsessed-with-fetchquests copycat's creation when you're climbing outcrops or buildings or trains--whatever. I liked this. I did. It felt old school, and since the game was going for an old school, very difficult fight for survival, it seemed right.

The game's difficulty, I felt, was perfect. I never died, but I was always coming close. There's a genuine sense of desperation start to finish, not only from you but from every NPC, enemy or friend--except maybe those aggressive armored ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s introduced at the 2/3rds point. Weird, annoying inclusion. You might find yourself sympathizing with many baddies.

Stick-ups" surprisingly lack the feeling of repetition from poor AI; despite their frequency
date: I always found myself with that feeling of desperation again
recommended: trying as quickly as possible to spot the guns before being forced to act and save some asses.\n\nThe storyline is lacking and feels more like a prelude than anything (reminiscent of Hard Reset)
hoursPlayed: but the atmosphere makes up for its inadequacies
voteText: ash and dust falling everywhere
helpfulPercent: choking the environment and its people--you--stressing that Road inspiration. (If I were to guess--and I really want to--I'd say The Event was an exaggerated eruption of one or more supervolcanoes.)\n\nI loved the feel of this game
votesHelpful: and I'll definitely replay it
votesTotal: hoping for further
votesFunny: bigger-budget sequels all the way through. I'd love to see how the world fairs outside of this game's geographic boundaries."

There's a genuine sense of desperation start to finish, not only from you but from every NPC, enemy or friend--except maybe those aggressive armored ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s introduced at the 2/3rds point. Weird, annoying inclusion. You might find yourself sympathizing with many baddies.

Stick-ups" surprisingly lack the feeling of repetition from poor AI; despite their frequency

reviewText:
Two apocalyptic game reviews from me tonight. I'm in the reviewing mood:)

Anyway first up is 'I am Alive' where a series of mega 'quakes has pretty much ruined everything. And your task is to seek your wife and child in your now destroyed home city, in 3rd person. The story and acting are nothing special but passable so we'll move on from there.
The ruined city is well designed and looks as you would expect a city to look after a huge earthquake. It's bleak and dusty, and crumbly.. and as you can imagine you have to travel over and under it. At times having to scale whats left of huge skyscrapers which gives a great sense of height as you scramble from ledge to ledge. The setting and soundtrack give an excellent apocalypic feel. It feels bleak and depressing,
It plays ok, but the combat is a bit clumsy. But you get used to it. And not everyone wants to kill you. Whether you help them all depends on what you are willing to sacrifice. It's not as linear as it seems either.

Recommended!

reviewText:
While I respect this game for trying to be fresh, it ended up feeling clunky and poorly-executed. On the good side, the story can be interesting and it's a fresh change from zombie apocalypse. Confrontations can also sometimes feel rewarding if you outsmart a group. The problem is that these good parts are rare. While the game teaches you the basics of combat early on, it also defies these at times. Also, the ending was horribly underwhelming.

Confrontations:
The game does a great job early on of showing you ways of dealing with multiple people and when you are underpowered (lacking ammunition for your gun) but it breaks many of the conventions established early on. For example, the enemy will rarely recognize the bow and arrow as a weapon and so, rather than stopping, they keep charging you. The enemy will also, after a while, charge you when you have a gun out (believing you have no bullets). This breaks the mechanic of shoving the enemy into fire or off cliffs since it takes so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ long to maneuver them into position while keeping your crosshairs on all the enemies. Another issue is enemy spawning. One particular sequence annoyed me to no end. You had to walk forward and get the attention of one group before a second group would open an impenetrable door and attack you from behind. You weren't allowed to sneak past one group or deal with them one at a time; you were forced to let them flank you.

Puzzles:
The game has a lot of climbing and maneuvering puzzles. I actually think this is its best quality and wish the game consisted purely of these sorts of puzzles and left out the clunky combat. Your climbing time is restricted by your stamina, which decreases over time as you climb. The first problem with this is that your character is incredibly difficult to control while climbing. I routinely found myself shifting along edges when I was pressing down to slide down the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ pole I was clinging to! Secondly, climbing is introduced in one of the hardest climbing puzzles in the game. With no guide or direction, the player has to complete one of the longest and hardest to deduce climbing paths in the game.

Story:
The story is pretty generic, but by the end I had some hope for it. We were saying goodbye to some main characters and the protagonist renewed his effort to reunite with his wife. And then the game ended. The game progressed to a state where, while not great, it was certainly improving. But instead of continuing the game, it just abuptly ends in a vague cutscene. I had only just gotten a second arrow for my bow.

In the end, this game seemed like it was trying to be a lot of things and failing at all of them. It was made by what appears to be a primarily Chinese team, so this may be their first entry into American games, but it felt very lacking in ways that cannot simply be excused by considering other cultures. Get this game if it's on super sale. If for nothing else, the guy who voices Adam Jensen in Deus Ex: HR plays a guy in a wheelchair here. So, if you want to hear the moody gravel voice, this is the game for you.

reviewText: This game was great. I loved the post apocolyptic atmoshere that is created by the dust filled air and crumbling cityscape. Everything feels like it's going to fall apart around you. The only thing I di not like was the ending. It was just so suden as if they just stopped writing and attempted to create an ending which felt really unsatisfying. I really wanted to know more about what was going to happen in this world. In colnclusion, I Am Alive is a very decent game and short game. It had all the right ideas but it just did not deliver a conlcusive ending.

reviewText:
It's not necessarily a great game but an interesting take on a third-person climber/survival set in a post-apocalyptic fictional city. There's not much I can say.

The story is generic but there are some interesting gameplay mechanics. You can use a gun (even if the clips are empty) to threaten and instill fear among hostile survivors and either choose to loot or kill them, or potentially leaving them alone. But I saw repetitive it's gotten.

But let's look back at the game's history. From what I remember, I am Alive was announced in e3 2008 (or 2009). It was shown with a CGI trailer. At the time, I thought this was gonna be a game similar to The Last of Us but I am Alive was delayed for so long. When it finally came out, we got this.

The current I am Alive which is on steam and other platforms was released as a downloable only title. So it never became a full retail game as originally promised.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It shows that this title went through development hell, which is an incredible shame. At it's core, it's a fantastic survival game. It features chilling atmosphere worthy of a space next to The Road. The gameplay is fun. It falls short in a few areas and is by no means perfect (it would be nice if there was a better stealth mechanic to the game). When it comes to the story, it's entertaining, but short with a very unresolved and abrupt ending---It feels as though the game's development hell caused only the first half of it to be completed.

The exploration levels would be fun if it wasn't for the incredibly aggrivating and pointless checkpoint save/retry system. You could spend 20 minutes exploring Haventon collecting loot only to die and have the game revert to the beginning of the level without retaining any of your found items.

All in all, there is enough here to make up for the pitfalls and make it worth playing, especially if it's on sale. It's a shame this game didn't do well for the studio. I would gladly play a sequel that was given a proper development cycle.

reviewText:
I Am Alive is a flawed, but surprisingly enjoyable survival game. You play a man searching for his family after a catastrophe destroys a large American city. Survivors live amongst the ruins, and many of them are willing to kill over a bottle of water or a can of food. Other survivors may need your aid, and it's up to you if you want to help them or not.

I Am Alive is something like a survival-horror game, even though it doesn't have traditional monsters. Combat sequences aren't that numerous, but they do require some planning since enemies usually outnumber you and bullets are very hard to come by. I Am Alive often puts you in situations where you're facing four armed enemies and you only have one bullet and your trusty machete. Combat in I Am Alive works but it's kind of clunky, with button prompts often appearing just a bit too late; It's manageable, but could have been better.

Not everyone in I Am Alive will be hostile towards the player: there are numerous survivors who require assistance of some kind. While you can help these folks out by parting with precious supplies, you don't have to. Saving some people might involve taking someone else's life, but do you want to waste a precious bullet to save a stranger? It's up to you, and the game never judges your actions (or inactions). I Am Alive tries to subtly steer players down the virtuous path but if you want to keep all the goodies for yourself, you can.

I Am Alive also has some platforming sequences where you have to scale crumbling skyscrapers while making sure your stamina doesn't run out. These parts can be tense, but they aren't very hard.

All these things combine to make I Am Alive a fairly engrossing experience. What the game really needed more of was some extra polish as it feels a bit cheap, with mediocre character models and animations. The graphics can be atmospheric, but Unreal Engine's Sand Blasted" filter is horribly abused and makes nearly everything look the same after a while; fans of the color grey will love I Am Alive. Enemy artificial intelligence leaves something to be desired too
date: as baddies will  often cower when you point a gun at them only to instantly forget you had a gun when you lower the weapon
recommended: only to suddenly remember you have a firearm when the gun comes back up and quickly go back to pleading for their lives. This behaviour is comical
hoursPlayed: but it kills the tension in a lot of parts.\n\nI Am Alive's ending also needed some work. The cliffhanger conclusion feels really rushed
voteText: and it leaves a couple of major plot points unresolved. It's a very disappointing finish
helpfulPercent: with almost no payoff. It feels like there's a level missing.\n\nFlaws aside
votesHelpful: I Am Alive still manages to be a pretty good game. Try it. You just might be pleasantly surprised."
