reviewText:
This game is brilliant. The depth and immersion of this game is unbelievable. There's no zombies. No irradiated monsters. Nothing like that. There's just people. And they act like people. Some just want to defend their home. Others want your stuff. The way you fight is fantastic as well. You fight with psychology, rather than your muscles. You'll almost always be outnumbered. You almost always won't have any ammo. Use your mind, surprise the bandits, and make them -think- that you have a bullet chambered in that pistol you're pointing at them. If you go in, gun up, you'll find yourself dead before you can even -try- and threaten them.
Overall, you'll hardly ever see the ruined city you're in. You'll barely be able to see a few feet in any direction. But then you'll climb up and out of the dust, and the world will just open up before your eyes.
One downside though, is it can occasionally go a little funny with the controls. This is a game where at times, it's quite plain that it's a port. But the slight irking from having your character shimmy along a ledge to the right, rather than climbing further up a building, is quite easily forgiven once you take everything else into stock.

I'd heartily recommend this game to anyone who is fond of the survivor Post-Apocalyptia genre, with a heavy emphasis on realism when it comes to combat and exploration.

9.5/10
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Sort of slow-paced thriller game.  The combat is weak, but it's an interesting spin on the usual mash-up of 'shooter' games.  You have to choose whether to run, shoot, stealth, or try to muscle out the fights.  Ammo is SO incredibly hard to find that it really makes you think about having a game plan before you just run in guns blazing.  But the combat is not why you play this game.  The environmental exploration, navigation, and stamina climbing are exhilirating.  Many times you're climbing hundreds of feet above the city streets, your stamina is inching closer to empty and you're putting forth max effort just to hang on before falling to your death.  That's where the game's strength appears.  The music and hud elements really get your heart pumping as you make quick decisions in this post-apocalyptic city.  Finally the element of helping various people around the city:  do you risk giving up your well-earned supplies to help out those around you in need, or will you need that when you're dangling hundreds of feet in the air and on your last breaths?  Overall 5/10
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The graphics are alright, nothing to write home about but not horrific.

The mechanics are interesting, I like the intimidation part and having to think about your actions (somewhat), I played it on survivor mode and it was hard... up until the hotel. Once I got past the hotel I managed to down everything with one arrow, until I got to the pier and got a second arrow at which point I didn't need a gun and ended the game on a mountain of ammo, the pier mission was also incredibly short, if they thought having large battles with a bunch of enemies would provide difficulty or make it all seem longer then they were wrong.

The items were all but useless, I could've started up my own community and fed them for years by the end of the game I had that much crap.

Saving people was... alright I guess, but having to trek the entire city to go back to someone you saw at the start of the game just before finishing the game to give them a tomato is taking the ♥♥♥♥.

I hate the way they separate segments of a mission, and that I never got to see what those horrific and scary looking mutant-ish shadows were in the dust clouds.

And the ending, my god the ending. While I won't join everyone in saying it's the worst ending in history, as we know that's not true. It did seem very rushed and I expected it in all honesty and it leaves a ton of loose ends.
Having said this, I believe it works very well as a cliffhanger, people complain that it gives you no closure and leaves you confused but that's what it's supposed to do and it does it well, I think that it leaves plenty of opportunity for another game.

To summarize, I do believe it is a good game and I respect what they were trying to do, and I enjoyed the mechanics (Except the ♥♥♥♥ing dust, nothing but a godamn hassle) I would suggest people pick it up and play on survivor for the experience of a tough game with nice platforming and a plot line tha

reviewText:
I am Alive is a realistic survival game. it looks like an adventurish action the way you control it, but your moves are always puzzling around how to survive.
Please take under consideration that this is a really old game although it was out just recently.
This title was being developed ever since 2003 but it was frozen due to lack of founding until ubisoft took it up.
This said, the game is old. Which can be seen in various ways.
Let's take this in parts.


The grahics of the game are nicely designed. The engine's abilities remind of 09s to 10s games. So it's not bad at all.
The environment is stanning IMO. You find yourself in a world that has ended. Nature's gone crazy.
There are asphyxiating sandstorms all over and the element of dust and fog is everywhere.
The dusty environment results into a vast way too back&white-ish area.

Buildings, streets, inner environments too, they are all so dusty that you are actually staying in a literally desert colored city.
There are meny nice ideas on the table. Earthquakes, fallen aircrafts, meta-apocalyptic views, half fallen skyscrapers, also nice places to hide, some nice areas to visit.
My only one complainment from this part is that although my rig was enough to support the game,
i had some rendering issues making my mouse view laggy without seeing the fps dropping (weird)

Gameplay
I found the gameplay to be really really interesting, and actually the main reason I loved it.
Realism. The whole time you are racing against the odds of running out of stamina.
Climbing buildings with bare hands and walking through the sandstorm forces you to keep finding places to rest yoru stamina for some seconds or else you'll die.
Also you have to keep scavenging to find canned food, water bottles, meds and a few more stuff.

If played smart enough you won't have serious problems, though youw ill feel the challenge if it.
Also guns. realistic circumstances as well. You start with a handgun and you barelly find bullets around. Your average ammo cap is goign to be around 2 shots.
Most of the time you will use the gun to bluff against bandits and looters.
A machine is going to be your main weapon, and a bow with only one arrow which can be retreaved from yoru victims.

Also there's an unlockable shotgun when helping a survivor.
The game really gives you ideas of things that could had been implemented. I am forgiving because of teh age of the game.
Lots of elements could add to teh fun like more stealthy skills and attacks or using traps.
This could have been one of the best surival games ever for me.

Story
Now this is a dissapoiting part. Story is that you are just a guy surviving trying to find his wife and kid.
The plot is that you end up helping a woman and her daughter find their way to safety. and stuff.
Your main missions are like 3 or 4. Nothing else.
The game was clearly cut off most of its material and concept. You can see that it's too incomplete.

Average
This is a pure example of taking a super awesome creation, and ♥♥♥♥ing its brains out due to producer lack of founding.
The game could have been one of the most awesome titles of its kind, and it ended up being short, lacking story, and probably cut off most of its original elements ending up in a low priced easy to forget game.
I feel really really sad for those who put teh efford to create the idea and start implementing it, at a time when meta-apocalyptic games were not even that mainstream at all, and then see their dream ending up as a scrap work put out for sale almost 10 ♥♥♥♥ing years later.
I hope ubisoft decides to make a sequel or a prequel.
Because the base of this thing right here has potential to give a much greater than average future creation.

reviewText: I felt like the objectives and areas were far too forced and like I didn't have the options that were portrayed in the trailers. Finding and using bullets only one at a time was contrived and made it obvious (I clearly currently have this single bullet so that I can break that single lock to go to the next space) and obligatory. The multi-level movement was difficult, contrived, and overall didn't feel right. As cool as it was to be rewarded for hanging off a building by a sewer pipe by being given access to the next area, dying six times because you didn't see and aim for the sewer pipe many seconds before the roof you're balanced on collapses for no reason is excessive. Honestly, I felt like the game's movement could have been replaced by a point and click system where the screen is presented to you all at once, then your monkey-man character climbs six stories up an elevator shaft with a child on his back because you clicked a single button. I wanted to absolutely love the game and was overall not just disapointed that it wasn't great, but crushed that it was actually bad.

reviewText:
Bleak,depressing, with no hope of survival. I Am Alive is one
game (for some time), has captured the feeling of being in a
post apocalyptic world with a sense of being in mortal danger
upon every turn whether its to engage/elude an enemy or
decisively pick apart a group in order to defuse unavoidable
threats.

Though challenging I Am Alive plays with a very
interesting subject the art of deception, to fool enemies with your
pistol into submission in order to take them out non-fatally, or
play bait to the unsuspected in order to disarm them of their
weapons.

I find this game to be rather underwhelming in
execution but it more than makes up for in the atmosphere and
somewhat unique idea of fight or flee moments. Strategy is key
in order to survive I definitely recommend this game to people
who are looking for a different change in pace and gameplay.

reviewText: I haven't played this game in months. It just sits their, idly, in my Steam library. I remember I bought this during my very first Steam sale, it looked intresting and I was up to play. What I did not expect was a dull storyline (At least for the first 95 minutes of the game, afterwhich I haven't played anymore), silly controls that often led me to fall off tiny ledges, and boring and monotonous gameplay. A few of the mechanics, like how to react to multiple or single people at once when they come up to you is intresting, but after doing it for the 5th time in 30 minutes, it quickly becomes boring and repitive. There are much better options out there.

reviewText: This game is an odd mix of console over-accessibility and inventive game design. I was most impressed by the combat system, which enables more believable scenarios where NPCs aren't faceless goons who mindlessly fight to the death. They actually negotiate grey areas of vulnerability, try to avoid pointless violence, and wait for moments of opportunity to strike. Only downside on the PC is that this is clearly a shoddy console port.

As I started playing this the athmosphere seemed like another one of endless survive zombie apocalypse" games. I didn't know much what is game about because I got it as a gift from dear friend. But after a few minutes it become clear that this is not generic zombie game. It does have an apocalypse element and though clues are given about what coused it the emphasis of the story isn't on that.

The game nicely combines platform and a bit of puzzle elements with survive mode. You play as a very capable and  determent character who is out to find his family in a city that suffered cataststrophe a year ago. In the process you encounter other people
recommended: some in need of your help and some that catastrophe drowe to crime and even canibalism.  You  are given some free  will and some of  your  actions will determin fate of others but all in all it is a pretty linear game that is focused on a protagonist story.\n\nGeneral problems with the game is its lenght which is way too short for a game of that price
hoursPlayed: lack of free will in full degree and some very annoying bugs. Also save system is terrible. It is an interested play to kill few hours but far from perfect game."

reviewText: Positive first impressions, but after few hours you'll realise that the game is going nowhere and if you won't get bored enough to give up befor finishing it, you'll certainly get frustrated and quit anyway. It certailny puts forward some interesting gameplay mechanics, but that doesn't matter, since there's only a handful of them and the game doesn't do a very good job at creating compelling story or interesting missions to complimet them. Later on it just gets repetitive and annoying.\n\nThe one thing I really liked was grim and convincing setting, but then again, it's dragged down by poor presentation - from bad graphics and underwhelming level design to awkward animations and wooden character models.

reviewText:
Not a perfect game, but I Am Alive is fun, got some decent platforming and interesting (though a bit repetitive) combat and a really enviroment design.
Other than some weirdly low quality textures here and there the quality is top notch and the levels are very moody though not as open as they could have been.

Advice: play the game in easy, the difficulty itself remains the same but you dont have to deal with limited lives which by the way, was a completely stupid idea.

Veredic: For a budget title it's pretty damn good.

reviewText:
ENGLISH and Italian Review  Recensione Inglese ed ITALIANA

English:

Talking about this game ain't easy. It starts with the best premises: An immersive post-apochaliptyc atmosphere, a peculiar gameplay and a nice character story. BUT, it has an incorporated achievement system, so it doesen't use the Steam one. And that's a thing that i HATE. Because it makes achievements totally useless. The only reason of having an achievement system, it's to have them saved in your account, so you can then be satisfied and show them off. If you can't do that, they're useless. But that's the least. It doesen't investigate the catastrophe AT ALL. You don't know why, you don't know how.
It lasts 6 hours MAX, counting the eventual failures. And the end is... is frickin fast. What do i mean for fast? Well, from the last mission onwards i had that feeling, like the developers had a short-term to finish the game, so they finished fit quickly and poorly. The last mission is just an enormus exaggerate and unrealistic fight with tons of enemies and the finale, well...
You dead. Wanna know how? Wanna know why? lol, no, you dead. You just see your daughter (Or wife, i can't really remember) that found your camera, watches your videos and cries. And you?? Well, you dead, lol. ...So, the end isn't that great. No deep and too fast. And so much disappointing. That said, i can't really vote NO" 'cause despite everything i enjoyed this little game a bit. Exluding the finale. The feeling i had

reviewText:
I am SO VERY HAPPY that I purchased this game as a Halloween special, I think I paid $3.00 for it. I have a special liking for post-apocalyptic games, but if I had paid full price for this I would have been very upset.

The game starts off promising, with a bleak color scheme and appropriate moody music as you're placed in the shoes of a character who's arrived at his home town, and is trying to find a way to his dwelling. You have a gun but no bullets. OK, fine. Mad Max didn't have bullets for his gun half the time, but it was still an unforgettable experience of a movie. You come to a bridge which has been blown to pieces, and the tutorial system helpfully prompts you to jump the gap here, climb the post there. OK, fine. Normally I have little patience for jumping puzzles, but Half Life had its share, and that was one of the best games I ever played.

And this is where the game betrays its console roots. And no, I'm not a PC purist. I own a PS2, and PS3, and a Wii. I grew up playing Nintendo. There are some wonderful console games out there. This is not one of them. Here is why: While climbling, you have a stamina meter. OK, fine. Realistic. No one can hang by their fingers indefinately. You have to climb smart, or you'll run out of energy and fall. But, the game doesn't merely expect you to use common sense. It presents a jumping/climbing puzzle that demands perfection. You have JUST ENOUGH energy to make it where you need to get to. If you waste ANY time, even so much as a tenth of a second, you're going to fail. And fail. And fail some more. After ten tries I was able to get close to my objective. After ten more tries I was able to begin a final reach to the sanctuary of a ledge. And that's as close as I got. After the seventh time of running out of energy and falling to my death within that final reach, I gave up. Any game that throws a puzzle like this at you, a puzzle where literally one tenth of a wasted second counts, at the very beginning of the game... Well, to quote Eric Cartman, Screw you guys
date: I'm going home." Some players would view this as a challenge. More power to them. I view it as frustrating and as lazy game design.\n\nTo be fair
recommended: I'm not doing this game justice by reviewing it after only an hour of gameplay. But I say if the first bite of a sandwich contains excrement
hoursPlayed: you have no one else to blame if you take a second bite. Or
voteText: God forbid
helpfulPercent: finishing the entire thing just because you paid good money for it. And scanning other reviews has indicated that this opening puzzle of frustration is only the tip of the iceberg.\n\nThe funny thing is
votesHelpful: I've spent far more time writing this review than such a game deserves. But if I save even one gamer from throwing away $15.00 on this
votesTotal: then my work is done here."

reviewText:
After about an hour of playing this game, here is my view of it:

[5/10] Graphics-wise, it's extremely white/bright and has that horrible grain effect that doesnt let you fully enjoy the beauty of the map that isn't actually there.

[5/10] Sound-wise, The audio was all over the place. I suppose the support for 5.1/7.1 surround sound was horribly done in the game, because any people that talked were always somewhere else than from where the sound was coming from.

[3/10] Controls-wise, the controls are a little irritating, and for me, getting the camera to move at all was a challenge. I would be dragging my mouse across my entire desk just for the game to recognise that I wish to turn (no, it isnt the sensitivity, something is stopping the camera from moving). This may just be me, but it made it un-playable and ruined the game within the first 5 minutes.

[1/10] Combat-wise, absolutely lazy. Ammo is extremely scarce, from what i've seen (and from other reviews), you constantly have only one bullet at your disposal. The only way to melee people is to get up-close and personal to them. while everyone is attempting stabbing you in the sides, you gotta walk up and press 'E' to attack. (I may be missing another form of combat/control, but trying over and over I couldn't find anything, correct me if I'm wrong).

[6/10] Story-wise, somewhat enjoyable. Even though the start is a bit cheesy, the story seems to have more pontential than anything else in the game. While only an hour in, however, I can't say much about it.

[3/10] Options-wise, there are almost no customization settings what-so-ever. In the video settings, you can change the brightness, the resolution, the aspect ratio, anti-aliasing, the graphic quality itself (low, medium, or high), FXAA, or VSync. This menu leaves you no room to really adjust the graphics for that 'high quality' look. The audio settings is just the volumes of main, music, voice, and sound effects. This doesn't bother me as much, but I was hoping for some options for surround-sound, coming from a semi-stealth game.

Overall I would say this game is about a 4/10 from my view of it within an hour of game-time. I may be missing more good things or bad things about the game, but so far this game wasn't worth it.

reviewText:
Bought this game when it was on sale for Halloween. For three dollars, yeah it'd be worth it. For full price? No.

In short, it's very simplistic and feels very lazy. The characters are laughably simplistic with very little background ever established... which would really help given the main character seems to have the skillset of an Assassin from the Assassin's Creed franchise. I really would like to know how he's able to scale bridges and parkour on the level he does.

For a game about survival in a post-apocalyptic world there's very little actual survival and more on-rails walking engagement to engagement. You can't scavenge from the rubble, can't check inside containers or trash cans. This by itself hurts immersion.

What totally kills the immersion is the fact that even the fights are puzzles. You have to kill certain enemies in certain ways and in a certain order or you're dead before you know it. Stranger still is the ability to carry just one bullet for your magazine-fed handgun. There's no simple melee, no way to counter someone running up on you and no way to grapple someone less than a foot away from you with a firearm.

Even the animations are lazy. There's a scene wherein the main character is carrying a child on his back and ends up having to use his machete to break a chain. Our hero then sheaths this machete into the child's character model.

In conclusion? Boring, frustrating and not worth it. For a much better urban survival experience I'd reccomend the Fallout franchise.

reviewText:
Was really excited for this game and picked it up during a sale. Initially I tried to run it on my Win7 64bit (GTX460 / 12gb RAM) and it just crashed after a few minutes regardless if I was in the game or in the menu. Gave it up for dead after loads of troubleshooting.

Now a year later I tried to start it up on my gaming laptop (Win8 64bit / GTX860M / 12gb RAM) and it would not detect the controller, has 5fps at any resolution over 1024x768, and everything stutters to the point of lag even if I'm running it at 800x600 on lowest settings. Gave up again after some troubleshooting.

The game not working on two completely different builds with different OS's is really lame. Think its time to give it up for good. :(

reviewText:
Well, many bad reviews about this title, isn't it?
I took some times to read a few of them myself before writting down these lines. Wanted to see the argumentation on them.
Seems like many of you guys forgot a thing, not Ubi nor Steam tried to sell you this game as a 60 bucks AAA titles!
This title is the result of Shangai Ubi department and was promoted and sold like half an indie game.
What does that mean? Well you paid 15$/euros for it, even cheaper if bought on sale and the game worths its price.
Yes it has the usual UBI patern. Gameplay is very similar to prince of persia titles for the climbing and accrobacies.
Graphics are not top-notch and maybe the story-telling is not at the same level than a Walking Dead or other games of this vein.
But the game is fun to play. THERE IS a story anyway. Thing that is not always true in every survivals these days.
combat mecanics are repetitives, but what combats are not, right?
Does FPS allow you anything else than change your weapon or shoot at a different part of your adversaire's body?
Our guy here have just a few and the difference and challenge when fighting a pack is to see who to shoot at first. That's a point many seem to have missed. You got a leader or one of the bandit have a gun, bring him down first, others will be calmed down and more easy to kill.
Bugs?
Didn't find any fault that was not mine, missed a timing on a jump or misspressed a wrong button. Those are bugs of gameplay people are arguing about.
Man, never buy a prince of persia game, I think you would throw your computer by the window...

So at the end, what the game is?

A good survival. Short but cheap, with a nice story and is fun to play. Sometimes hard, never impossible.

reviewText:
I Am Alive might be one of the most ambitious and under-rated XBLA games of all time.

The niceties that are usually reserved for AAA gaming experiences are all present here. The soundtrack is stunning, the gameplay is innovative, and the atmosphere is remarkable.

That said, there are some problems with this game that do need to be addressed.

For one, there's a grainy filter that runs over the screen for the entire game. This isn't a glitch, but a purposeful design choice by the developers, presumably to make the game feel more gritty (or something). I don't quite understand the need for it, and it makes the game look pretty ugly.

There's also a stamina bar that slowly drains as you exert energy in the game, either by climbing buildings or traversing through the thick fog in the streets. When the bar gets about halfway down, the un-settling sound of shrieiking violins will fill your ears, indicating that your character doesn't have much longer to survive. This cranks the tension up to 11 during moments that might otherwise be a monotonous trudge, but by the 9th or 10th time it happens, you'll be looking for any excuse to avoid making your stamina drop. By the 50th time, you'll be taking off your headphones, setting them on your desk, and shaking your head in dissapointment. Sure, it's scary, and the sound sends chills up my spine, but there's no relief from it. That dreadful buzz will accompany nearly every moment of this game. It begins to feel like a cheap way to add horror into a game that really isn't that horrifying.

Other than that, I Am Alive is captivating. The intimidation" style combat feels excellent and believeable. Enemies will cower under your gun while you're pointing at them

recommended: they'll start to think you're bluffing

reviewText:
Absolutely a massively underated game. Yes its an xbox 360 port but with the new patch update and controller support, its quite beautiful in two ways. Graphically, yes its dated graphically but atmospherically it more than makes up for it. I personally really like the washed, sun bleached look. It all works brilliantly to be another character in itself. Bleak, dusty and desperate. You will stair in wonder at the sun glare and vista's through broken building windows, but despair about looking down to the dust soup below that you know you have to delve into.
The second positive is its combat is a really great attempt at different. You are taught to think about using the tools they give you with such an incredibly limited ammo supply, seriously limited. I have used the same one arrow for my bow in nearly every battle.
The added genius of a taunt option where you threaten with your pistol so that thugs back away at its sight and beg not be shot is great. However they will grow in confidence if you taunt to much and call your bluff realising that the gun is actually empty. Then they may attack, so will you machete, use the bow or run. You will die in this game, but each time it teaches you this is survival, so survive. It has a very standard but competent climbing and traversing mechanic which does its job well with good animation, although our hero does choose his own path occasionally.
If I have one gripe its that the save system is spread out quite a bit and when you have exhausted your in-between checkpoint tokens, gathered for saving civilians along the way, you will be sent back quite a way to a previous save point, and with this loose a lot progress that you may have made.

This game rewards exploration if you wish to risk it but with such intermitant saves points it also holds exploration back somewhat which is its only slight issue.

For a couple of pounds on steam, even if you pay a fiver i highly recommend this little gem. Think 'Shadow of the collosus' meets 'the last of us' and you are there.

reviewText:
+Atmosphere: Grey, dusty, bleak and dark. Just like a post-apocalypse should be.

-Movement/Exploration: Most of the game time is spent trying to navigate, run, and climb your way from point A to point B. Frustrating for many gamers, but logical and realistic enough.

-Equipment: Not much diversity, but then again, you ARE in a city that's been a wasteland for many months.

+Story: The main character is an office worker, not an ex-navyarmy overpowering rambo. He wants to meet his family, not save the world.
The enemies are everyone that doesn't need anything from you
No Zombies.
The teaser at the ending left me itching for the sequel; though I must admit I expected a more fulfilling ending.

++Stamina: Almost every action requires stamina, so excessive movement is a no-no. If you run out of stamina during a physically demanding task, you start using your health as stamina, which isn't far from what happens in real life.

+++Combat: One enemy is doable. Two are iffy. Three require tactics. Any more without a bullet would be suicide without climbable ledges to run to.
Fighting has the most realistic mechanic I've seen in a survival game. Feints and bluffs are the only means with which you may survive against overwhelming numbers (>2=overwhelming).


Overall: The best cross between a survival simulation and a survival game I've ever tried.

reviewText:
+Atmosphere: Grey, dusty, bleak and dark. Just like a post-apocalypse should be.

-Movement/Exploration: Most of the game time is spent trying to navigate, run, and climb your way from point A to point B. Frustrating for many gamers, but logical and realistic enough.

-Equipment: Not much diversity, but then again, you ARE in a city that's been a wasteland for many months.

+Story: The main character is an office worker, not an ex-navyarmy overpowering rambo. He wants to meet his family, not save the world.
The enemies are everyone that doesn't need anything from you
No Zombies.
The teaser at the ending left me itching for the sequel; though I must admit I expected a more fulfilling ending.

++Stamina: Almost every action requires stamina, so excessive movement is a no-no. If you run out of stamina during a physically demanding task, you start using your health as stamina, which isn't far from what happens in real life.

+++Combat: One enemy is doable. Two are iffy. Three require tactics. Any more without a bullet would be suicide without climbable ledges to run to.
Fighting has the most realistic mechanic I've seen in a survival game. Feints and bluffs are the only means with which you may survive against overwhelming numbers (>2=overwhelming).


Overall: The best cross between a survival simulation and a survival game I've ever tried.

reviewText:
This game is highly underrated and has been given a questionable rating.
This is possibly the top game in terms of a post-apocalyptic setting and gives players a pure believable survival experience. It's atmospheric setting in a darker world that we all know, and a plot to keep us enticed until the end shows us a gripping; captivating; depressing; miserable; and almost always utterly brilliant game.
The crafty and clever use of a dust-filled city may make up for the graphics that have been questioned but I am quite comfortable with how they are regardless.
An interesting feature, which I would love to see more in games, is their use of the gun. We can stick people up. Literally, if you want something in this world you can point your gun in their face and watch as they cower. You can do the right thing and help people with supplies that are scarce, or rob them.
Do not underestimate the scarcity of supplies because as I said before, it IS the most believable survival experience.

I actually felt like I robbed them for getting this on sale :/

Epic game and I am still looking for another game like it. 9/10

reviewText:
This game is nearly everything I wanted from a Post-apocalyptic game! It was still a whole lot different than I imagined, but in a good way. Unfortunately you can definitely tell that this game wanted to be more than it is, as it is missing some stuff which would have made this game even better; but I'll get back to that.

It's a good game that shows us that Zombies aren't the threat in a post-apocalyptic world (not that there are zombies in this game) but that people are threat. In this game you might hear someone crying for help, but it could just be a trap set in place so they can rob you of well you're life. So you have to beware of who you help and don't help. Also since items are very scarce, you have to ask yourself if you want to help this person giving him/her your last health pack or do you keep it for yourself. These are great questions but to my dismay the choices you make don't really impact the game.

If you for example help someone, they usually just say thank you and you get an extra retry.  In fact the only reason to help someone in this game would be to get the achievement for helping all victims in the game. If however helping someone would impact the story line; for example the person you saved ends up helping you later in the game or perhaps you helped the wrong person, and that person later then screws you over in the story. Well I think you can imagine that would have made the choices in the game so much more interesting. Now theyre just NPCS that stare at you after you help them...well umm great.

So yeah theres a lot of potential for this game to be the best post-apocalyptic game ever but it unfortunately just misses the mark. I also feel like the fighting options are quite limited but maybe im just bad at the game. Either way I still found it a really enjoyabel game to play, and I do think I will replay the game again at some point just to save all the victims in the game. However the missed potential in this game stares at me with every NPC you save (they literally just stare at you). It's just such a shame no one has tried to improve on this concept because that would make the best post-apocalyptic game ever!!!

In conclusion, you should get this game! but feel free to wait for a steam sale. As long as you play 6 euros or less, it is worth it as you will definitely get 6 hours of gameplay; even from a rushed playthrough!

reviewText: The game I am Alive was made by Darkworks from 2005-2008 and switch midway through to Ubisoft Shanghai And was released in 2011 on Xbox live arcade,PSN,and Microsoft Windows.For a game that was in development for over 5 years this game should be close to flawless but instead the game is incredibly bland and feels like it was made in 2 days by one guy.this is a post apocalyptic game after some thing caused the world to go to hell,Whatever caused this series of events to happen isn't explained at all.You play as Adam Collins a man trying to find his family after he went on a buisness trip across the country before everything went down.At the start of the game you watch a tape recording of him talking to who ever can find it and tells them what he has with him,He has a Bag,rope and a gun which he hasn’t used yet,but fires like a pro during gameplay.Without spoiling to much the the story is really just about him finding his family.The gameplay in this game is god awful.The camera switches from 3rd to 1st person,the enimeis dont die by a machete to the face or a bullet to the heart ,the gun is useless,the controls are afwul,the A.I is rediculous,the story is bland and boring, the stamina is so bad if you run for 2 seconds you become very tired or if your climbing you just fall off and die.This isnt a game its a joke.The only real “good” thing about this game is the world is very well done and the graphics are good.The price i would reccomend buying this for is if and only if this game becomes free to play.Overall I would have to give this game a 17/100.Thats being generous.

reviewText: All around good game. Graphics aren't spectcular, but its not really a problem. Has the atmosphere of the Last of Us, but thats about it. Gameplay is best described as a puzzler. You have to think before you act otherwise youll more than likely die. I don't really like that one mistake makes it 99.9% you'll die, but I guess that's a bit more realistic. Some moments seemed really challenging, and were almost too difficult at times, at least in terms of combat. Climbing aspect was fun and a good way to challenge your mind. However in terms of control, it could be unresponsive. trying to slide down a pole could cause you to move left or right several times instead, (which if you play you'll understand why it can be frustrating) and aiming, shooting, attacking could also freakout at times, but mostly aiming because of accidental switching between targets. Armored enemies were kind of OP because there were only two weak points, and because of tedious aiming capability made it hard to be accurate. Stealth was hardly even an optin because as soon any of the characters are in visual range they react, and most are placed in a way that makes it impossible. Player interaction with NPC's was limited to combat, or helping them out. the decision making was kimited to Do I have the item they need or not
date: and am I willing to spend the time to get it?" And finally the ending seemed abrupt
recommended: and was a cliffhanger that made no sense. However the characters were enjoyable. I'd say maybe 6 or 7/10"

reviewText:
Let me begin by saying when first seeing the original announcement trailer for I Am Alive, I was extremely excited. The concept was very interesting and while it seemed to be an action game there were large psycological aspects to the play style that could make for a dynamic and unique game. After a long while I had forgotten about the game and assumed it to be vaporware only to suddenly find it alive on steam, no pun intended. I immediately seized it and excitedly dove right in. Disappointment set in quickly and I now wish it had stayed lost, maintaining my fantasy of what it might have been.

I Am Alive is a post-apocalyptic survival game. Food, resources, and ammunition are scarce and people have devolved into animalistic cliques who follow a kill or be killed morality. You come in one year in the aftermath of a great earthquake which has destroyed your home town of Haverton. Looking for your wife and daughter you meet with Mei, a young girl who you connect with and decide to protect. My first qualm with this game comes with its flimsy plot line. The game immediately begins with a clear set goal in mind and then immediately falls off track and begins following a long series of tangents to a quite unfinished ending. Along this way you meet various crooks and characters of whom you only learn of three names leaving the rest as expendables with whom you make no connections. Rewards for helping these people are generally bland and unsatisfying despite considerable effort and padding in order to help them. Worse, while many could easily have something interesting to say or do, they rather instead go straight to a generic need item, recieve item, thank you formula. Enemies are just as bad, consisting of roughly 4 or five different character models and all resulting in the same action to solve the problem, kill the one with the gun first, kill the rest second. The game gives the appearance of giving options without presenting the other choices. There isn't really a diplomatic way to deal with enemies (ordering to surrender, bribing them to leave, tying them up), and if you're lucky after killing half of them, one may offer to let you knock him unconcious. My initial interest in this game came from the idea of having alot of ways to handle enemies and being given the choice between the easy way, murder, and the hard way diplomacy and mercy.

Items are scarce in the game, but not very scarce apparently. There are some 20 different items in the game all performing some combination of the same three functions, restoring stamina, restoring strength, and restoring health. While a particular item may be scarce there seems to be no end the items to fill any one of these purposes. If you only have a single soda can you most likely have come across 6 or 7 water bottles, for example. Each of these items at some point can be used to help a victim solve a problem but it is frustrating when you do not have an item on your one chance meeting with a particular victim. In many cases its even more frustrating when an item serves no other real purpose but to help this victim, despite the item being readily available (cigarettes and wine). Along with this many of the victims seem to need this item only for the purpose of giving an item something to do (again cigarettes and wine). It again adds to the unfinished feeling the game gives.

The environment in the game is . . . well, gray. Exteremly gray in fact. I understand the idea of soot and ash covering the town making it this way but there is a serious lack of any color in this game indoors or out. I mean orange fire, yellow dust, red brick,  and blue water bottles should not be outside the realm of possibility. I originally thought that my character was severly injured and this was some sort of indicator of his deteriorated state, similar to other survival games, however that is the entire game. While the intent was clearly to give the player the feeling of depression washing over the city, it goes from sad to boring quickly. Action scenes feel drab and uninteresting when not only repetetive  but also made up of a single constant color throughout the short five hour playthrough. Did I mention short? Cause five hours was the entire game, padding and all. The core gameplay of I Am Alive could be broken down to one hour of actual play time and 4 hours of walking through dust cloud and climbing. While climbing mechanics in certain games such as Uncharted or Tomb Raider have been made exciting by quick time events, and active gameplay through the process, I Am Alive has made the sequence tedious. Adding the stamina bar would be an interesting twist on the game if it did not add to the padding between actual gameplay.

Overall probably the biggest let down in game history, and that includes Duke Nukem. I hope the developers can sleep alright at night.

reviewText:
I really dig this game for a lot of reasons, but foremost is the combat. Here's how the last encounter I had went when I finally nailed it after running low on the hard-to-come-by retries.


I walk into an area and am surrounded, 2 guys behind me and 3 in front. I quickly note that 2 of the guys are armored (one being behind me), the second man behind me has a gun, and the other 2 simply have knives. I also notice a bonfire in the corner. Then I make my plan and execute.

First I back up without revealing that I'm armed or willing to fight. However, the guy who approaches me is the armored guy who was behind me. Since he's armored, I can't kill him with a quick knife. So I continue backing up for a couple seconds until the only guy behind me is the one with a gun, and then I strike.

I attack the gunman with my surprise strike, killing off the gunner and leaving the 4 others in front of me without a way to get between me to the dead man's gun. I then have to immediately toggle to precision aim, and aim quickly to shoot the armored man who was harassing me before he slashes me and while the other 3 enemies approach.

Once I shoot the first armored man pointblank, I can quickly cycle between the 2 unarmored men and convince them to start backing up, realizing that I have a gun with ammo. The 2nd armored man continues approaching with his bulletproof vest, so I have to quickly switch to precision aiming and shoot him in the head.

At this point there are 2 men with knives left. I tell them both to keep backing up, separating them and forcing one to back up to the fire. I then kick the poor man into the fire to die, and quickly turn as the final man starts sprinting at me when he realizes I'm still looking to kill. I choose to save the 1 round of ammunition that I have left, and catch him in a one-on-one knife battle, knowing that I can finally win it without his buddies around to save him.


I walk away from 5 dead bodies with only 1 round of ammunition left, wondering how I can make it out of an even larger battle next time.


I highly recommend this game. It has its flaws, but it's easy to look past them with combat as thrilling and intense as this.

reviewText:
This game is for serious post apocalyptic fans only.  I really wanted to love it but I just can't recommend it for the average gamer.

Pros
Great level design, atmosphere, and textures
Okay story...good dialogue

Cons
Horrendous controls (total console port)
Camera control issues
Fighting system is teh suck
Very hard

There are some interesting ideas with the combat; the main one being you can use your gun to psych people out eventhough you may not have ammo.

If you play this, I recommend doing it on Easy so you doing spend eternity replaying chapters.  It kind of being a sandbox (in that there are generally several ways to get to the same place) it does not allow for exploration very easily.

The main mechanics are completely derived from the PS2 game Disaster Report, which in my mind created this genre of Tomb Raider platformer + management of health + disaster scenario.  Which is a good thing.  It means you really need to plan your actions especially while climbing.

If you like climbing stuff and post apocalyptic environments, then it should be good. Otherwise, I would not bother.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I am alive: Bleak and unforgiving

This game has an awesome premise.
This game has an awesome amount of potential.
This game has an awesome difficulty curve.

WHAT THE HELL HAPPENED?!?!?!
How did they go from having so much awesomeness to ending up with this drek?
In the guise of having an open world that you cant spend too long exploring. If you do you will die. Not from world hazards, which are awesome, but from there not being enough things in the game to live off if you want to go for a jaunt in the dust and explore the world a little. Which is something you need to do TOO survive.
You are only guaranteed to find what you need by following the story.
The grey mono colour environment is a problem for me. It works well when you are actually out in the dust, its necessary and a unique hazard in games. My problem with it is the colour scheme continues when you are not even out in the dust.
The Game play is a little cluncky but I can forgive it for that. It makes the otherwise rail-road movement system a little bit more challenging.
The story is an interesting point to think about. Those who have read my other reviews know that it is the driving force behind my game purchases, It HAS a story but you are not following it because you want to you are following it because you HAVE too. It is the only way to find the resources you need to get through the game.
Combat is ingenious and original. You have to make a decision about every bullet you use and every fight you get into. The problem is you lack the ability to swing your machete... Yeah I know how that sounds but think about it for a moment. You cant shoot your way out since you will never have more than 4 bullets in your gun, you will never have more than 5 arrows for your bow but it takes too long to draw making it unusable in close combat. The machete can only be used in combat when you are struggling with an opponent. You cant do that if there is more than one enemy because you will get ganked from behind by your opponents mate. The only bonus is you can pick up arrows after you have shot them if you can find them again! My advice on that one is DO NOT MISS!

I give this game a 5/12
Story: Awesome premise but.. (see below)
Combat: A pain in the ♥♥♥
World: Imaginative but mono tone.
World design: Restrictive.
Graphics: Good.
Characters: Believable.






**Spoiler Alert**
Scroll down.













The real sore point is that the story is never resolved! You spent the whole game chasing your objective only to get to the end of the game not having found your objective and seemingly forgotten about it all together at points.

reviewText:
I Am Alive was one of those games for me. It’s sort of a survival game set in a post-apocalyptic United States of America. You play as some guy with a forgettable name after he has walked across the entirety of the United States after “the Event” to find your wife and daughter. I remember when the demo came out and I tried it having mixed feelings about it. You can tell that Ubisoft really wanted to show off the climbing engine they use for Assassin’s Creed in other venues. Unlike Assassin’s Creed where you can use your free running to get around the city in a number of different ways I Am Alive simply has you going on one set path. The climbing and exploration is done well in I Am Alive, the stamina bar was a nice touch. You can only run or climb until you run out of stamina and after that you have to mash the right trigger which will deplete how much stamina you can recover, if not you’ll end up falling to your death. And if that sounds like too daunting of a challenge fear not! You can scavenge different supplies as you make your way through the city like food, water, and medical supplies. So if you’re running out of stamina you can just drink a bottle of water as you’re climbing and you’ll be alright.

Combat is the other major obstacle that you’ll encounter and it wasn’t done as well as I expected. You start off the game with empty pistol and some enemies you intimidate and some you have to kill but it always seems to be random chance. You’ll run into other enemies with guns and even though bullets are really hard to come by and it would seem that you can’t have any more than four bullets in your gun your enemies will have full magazines and extra clips. Combat is messy and I always dreaded walking into a conflict but perhaps that is what the developers were aiming for, trying to drive home how hard it is to survive in a post-apocalyptic world.

I came into I Am Alive being on the fence about it. The demo left a bittersweet taste in my mouth and the entire game isn’t very long at all. The game ended right when things were getting good and I left with more questions than when I began. There are other NPC survivors that you can help by getting them certain resources in exchange for information about your family and maybe doing that would have given a better story ending, I’m not sure I don’t usually strive for 100% completion when I struggle with a core mechanic of gameplay , like combat. I think I Am Alive would work really well as an episodic game with what is already released being the first episode. I thought that they were working with an interesting premise which I wouldn’t mind seeing a little more of once it’s been fine-tuned and had some of the bugs worked out of it.

reviewText:
I Am Alive is a bleak, depressing game. This doesn't make it a bad game. In fact, I think the atmosphere is quite good. In terms of the game itself the story is quite simple. A catostrohpic event happened while you were out of town. It has taken you a year to get back to your town and you are now trying to find your wife and child. On your quest to do this, you become connected with another family and you complete missions for them.

The game is brutally hard even when not on the hardest difficulty. You have scare resources and you have a stamina meter that prevents you from climbing or running forever. Also, saving the game only happens at random, spread-out times that are not controlled by the gamer. I imagine this is one of the main reason the game got beat up by critics.

Overall, I loved it even though it was completely bleak.

reviewText:
I Am Alive is such a peculiar game. It's one of those games that I play, and don't really enjoy, but want to keep playing. I mean, The game is very ambitious, and I'm having some amount of fun with it, but there's just some things about it that you can't help but think how this game may have benefited from some different design choices.

I enjoy the challenge that the limited continues provide.  It makes you want to play the game more carefully. I feel like the game rewards you for exploring, as you find additional items, and sometimes survivors to help, which will give you an additional retry, but it also punishes you by making your stamina go down, making you almost not want to explore.

It's little things like that where the game is sending you mixed messages where it starts to feel like a chore to play. Yet, then I end up raiding an area with a whole bunch of enemies, and I have to carefully pick & choose my next move, trying to make people surrender, or pushing them far enough back to kick them off a ledge, or getting close enough to stab them with my machette. all the while, I'm making sure I do them all in the right order and quick enough in order to avoid getting hit, and conserving my ammo, which is very precious.  Some might find this tedious and complicated, but I find it tense & exhilirating.

After you get through an area, just fighting group after group of guys, the game just makes you feel like this awesome Mad Max kind of character, and it's those moments, and the story (which is somewhat basic but kind of intriguing) that keeps me coming back to it.

The game is definitely not for everyone, and it has it's flaws... but for people who enjoys survival horror games, or just games with interesting systems and mechanics, I'd say to definitely check it out.

reviewText:
I Am Alive was once a survival horror game with big dreams and high hopes. When first conceived, it was purposed to be set in an explorable, expansive, post-apocalyptic world with deep gameplay mechanics focused on human interaction in times of crises. But two years after its ambitious beginnings, the original developers, Darkworks, handed the project off to Ubisoft Shanghai. In its new home, I Am Alive was rebuilt as an arcade title with many of its intended features either removed or condensed. So how does it fare in its current state?

I had not heard much about I Am Alive prior to release, but if its original narrative was anything like the final product, then the idea probably was not very good to begin with. The game takes place a year after America is struck by a massive earthquake known as “The Event.” You play as an unnamed survivor, separated from and in search of his family—at least, that is how the story begins. The plot makes a sudden shift early in the game and becomes centered on the protagonist helping reunite someone else’s family for the remainder of the campaign. By the time we reach the end credits, our protagonist’s personal mission has made almost no progress. Some may find this hugely unsatisfying, though I suppose in some ways, it is poetic and fitting to such a morbid game.

While I Am Alive’s narrative is devoid of creativity, its gameplay mechanics fortunately are not. Being aware of your surrounding is pivotal to survival. “The Event” has left much of America uninhabitable, filling the atmosphere with ash and dust, and to escape the hazardous environment, you must scale structures high enough to reach fresh air. This process eventually loses its novelty after the first few times, but it deters players from rushing and encourages exploration. But the most innovate idea I Am Alive offers is the idea to threaten and bluff. I say “idea” because its implementation is just deeply, deeply flawed. During confrontations, you may raise your pistol, loaded or not, to halt enemies in their tracks. At this point, the ability to negotiate would have been a hugely welcomed feature, but alas, the system never gets deeper. The moment you look away, your enemies will attack, rendering threats extremely useless since you are forced to kill regardless.

I Am Alive’s single redeeming element is its atmosphere, which captures all the greatest facets of survival horror. The thick dust at ground level obscures vision beyond a few feet from your character. The element of surprise comes from not knowing who or what you will run into until it is too late. Ammo is extremely scarce, and your character is fragile, so knowing when to flee or fight becomes essential. Dying NPCs taking refuge throughout the city convey a genuine sense of desperation and futility. This is survival horror done right.

Atmosphere and missed ideas aside, nothing else about I Am Alive is very memorable. The graphics are bland, the soundtrack forgettable, and the animations clunky at best. There are side quests, but those are far and few in between. Remnants of Darkworks’ original ideas are still apparent in the final product, but all of them marred by poor execution. I sincerely hope that Darkworks’ vision will resurface one day, refined and in all its entirety. Until then, you should find your survival horror fix elsewhere.

Grade: 2/5

reviewText:
Set in a dark and dusty post-apocalyptic world, I Am Alive is pretty damn gritty. When you first boot up the game you may think the developers are aiming for a monochrome art style to reflect the emptiness of the world and the protagonist. Nope - it's just really, really dusty. Everything (seriously, everything) in the game is black, white, brown, or somewhere in between, with occasional splashes of red (to create an industrial feel as well as the obvious reason).
Follow the exploits of Professor Brian Cox as he tries to find his family, help fellow survivors, and explain the Pauli exclusion principle to increasingly ignorant and hostile thugs. At times, this is deep, rewarding, and engaging stuff.
Unfortunately for the Professor, his resources are somewhat limited. Our Lancastrian hero's weaponry is limited to his machete and a pistol. However, the latter seems to be used more as a mechanic for conserving resources than as a weapon, as bullets can only be found from enemies who have...guns! Combat can therefore become frustrating as confrontations with thugs are common and it's difficult to know who to shoot first and who to leave for a struggle kill with your machete.
This isn't the only time tactics are needed for conserving resources, however, as Professor Cox regains health and stamina through the rare packets of food and drink that he finds perched on outcrops and crates by a fellow survivor who presumably didn't want to make things to easy for those after him.
The game revolves around stamina and climbing as Professor Brian must scale increasingly dizzying heights during each episode. Despite his PhD in physics, the Professor's stamina depletes frighteningly quickly making each section of climbing a nail-biting game of tactics. Thankfully, as seen above, Brian can have snacks while hanging from girders to give him a boost. How this is meant to work in real life exactly I have no idea.
So what happens when the Professor falls to his death, or some thugs grow tired of hearing about eleven-dimensional M-theory and slaughter him with machetes? Well, on Normal" mode he'll be given three retries for each "episode" which will allow him to revert to a checkpoint a few minutes of gameplay back. It soon becomes apparent
recommended: that given the maze-like webs of scaffolding Professor Cox must negotiate and how difficult is to know which enemies to eliminate first on so few bullets
hoursPlayed: these retries really aren't enough. It's not uncommon to have to retry up to twenty minutes of gameplay following a clumsy death near the end of one "episode". The game only saves at the end of each 20-30 minute episode
voteText: so get ready to sit down for long periods at a time with this game.\nAlthough we're used to Brian gazing dreamily up at the stars as though he wouldn't hurt a fly
helpfulPercent: the game's moral direction is altogether more ambiguous. You're rewarded for helping injured survivors and reuniting friends and family
votesHelpful: but more frequently you're forced into combat you don't want or need. I would have liked to have seen a less linear path through levels
votesTotal: with some scope for stealth and avoiding conflict.\nWhen the game works
votesFunny: it works well and flows nicely. Although some of the events in the game feel jarringly too convenient (early on an earthquake pushes over a building
commentsCount: allowing you to slide down the wall back to where you started form and the next checkpoint)

reviewText:
I Am Alive can best be likened to watching a car crash in slow motion - while being in the car. If you happen to be colorblind, worry not, all gamers can experience the same 3-4 shades of grey over and over again as you stumble about through clouds of film-grain, each of which is strategically placed to hide anything more than 10 meters away in any direction. What the game lacks in entertainment value or graphics, it makes up for with characters so deep that they very nearly have two dimensions.

- Fight no one for ages, then five identical groups of thugs one after the other!
- Explore a world where dust is as deadly as machete-wielding bandits and tinned peaches can heal stab wounds!
- Play as Rico Rodriguez on your quest to take a little girl back to Adam Jensen and possibly more!

I Am Alive - but when playing this I wish I wasn't.

reviewText: This game can be very challenging at times but it is excellent! I'm not into moving around the level in a Prince of Persia style game but this game may've changed my mind. The story is quite good also and the atmosphere reminds me of fallout without the Sci-fi element and feels somewhat more like the Book of Eli. Some of your situations will have you thinking of the moral implications of your actions and I love that in my games. Albeit this game was short, and a few of the controls were a little sketchy, that pales in comparison to just how good this game was.\n\nIt was a lot of fun and I would recommend it to anyone! I rate it at a solid 9 out of 10.

reviewText: Great idea, terrible execution.  I am only playing it because I like the concept but the gameplay is total ♥♥♥♥.  It has been out for 7 days now and the mouse lag is not fixed. reviewText:
Such an amazing game. Before anything, I should say that it's purely singleplayer and somewhat linear but not as restricted I think.

The game takes place in a post-apocalyptic future where the world is pretty much ruined from massive earthquakes, it's a pretty hostile world and almost everyone is pretty much against you all the time. But you're not defenseless and not everyone is out to chop your head off either, some are in need of your help and some are just trying to protect themselves. Big fish eating the small fish and all that. You can choose to help them or just carry on.

The game mechanics are pretty decent yet nothing special. Combat is intense and fun most of the time, although it's more realistic and suspenseful rather than action shooter style. You can intimidate the enemies with your gun, kick them into chasms or go melee with your machete, most of which works the good old jappy way of tapping certain keys but without going DDR" like in Resident Evil or similar games."

reviewText:
This game. It's...well it's different. If you like survival games then you should enjoy the bleak atmosphere and setting, but as the levels aren't massively open world, looking for supplies only requires you to take the less obvious route to your goal.

Gunplay (and later on, arrow play) requires thinking and timing, as you only have 1 bullet vs 4 enemies at many points in the game. Again this adds a survival aspect to the game. If you are a fan of bleak miserable stories, then also conisder buying this game. It is one of the few arcade games that actually has a decent story.

The thing this game is probably most well known for, and hated for, is the retry system. You pick up retries" through the game by helping people
date: (by giving them your supplies) or just finding them lying about. Retries basically let you start from last saved checkpoint. Out of retries? Then you will have to start that level that you have been playing for an hour all over again. It's quite similar to Dead Space 2's Hardcore mode
recommended: where you only get a few saves (albeit not as harsh).\n\nThe last gameplay element I will look over is the most important
hoursPlayed: and may influence you buying it. The stamina bar. The stamina bar is used up for almost anything except walking. It regenerates very quickly but only when walking. If you are halfway up a building
voteText: you can't just stop and rest
helpfulPercent: you either use up precious supplies
votesHelpful: or die. When your stamina bar is empty you enter a mode called "extreme effort" which lets you push on through whatever you are doing (climbing
votesTotal: walking through dust clouds etc.) but then actually drains the capacity of your bar
votesFunny: which means less stamina regenerates each time you rest. This therefore
commentsCount: means climing is more supply dependant
column16: unless you refill your bar to full capacity. For people who tend to not think things through before doing something
column17: this game will not be for you. Unless you don't mind starting a level over every time you die.\n\nI played the game on the hardest difficulty from the outset and have only died 5 times between level 1 and 11
column18: so it is easily done.\n\nIn conclusion
column19: this game I recommend on sale
column20:
as it only lasts about 5 hours but the story and satisfaction of surviving will make sure you do not regret the price.

reviewText:
I Am Alive is a survival game which focuses on heavy player choices and immersing the player. While i thought the game was really good and worth the money some may not and here is why:

Dated graphics
Clunky controls
And a buggy camera which sometimes won't move.

But me being a fan of post apocalyptic themes i decided to look past all of this and what i saw was awesome, while not all will like that kind of gameplay i loved it. You are able to bluff enemies with a empty gun but some of them will stop up and say your full of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and encourage others to attack. I thought that was a awesome thing i had not seen before, you also need to switch targets sometimes to keep them afraid of being shot. Another key factor is the extremely rare supplies which you need but you only have 3 retry's or you have to start over. Additional retry's can be aquired by giving away supplies and medicine to people, so that keeps the game tense.
The soundtrack which i found really good is also a indicator for when climbing buildings since the soundtrack becomes more intense as you lose stamina. 0 stamina results in falling down and dying.

Overall i found the game to be really good and worth my money since i played it three times. But keep in mind this is a arcade game so it only last for about 5 hours on average.

reviewText:
I looked at the description in the store for I Am Alive and thought it was a neat concept.
I played the game, and there wasn't a moment I wasn't happy with it.
It wasn't ground breaking, nor was it particularly beautifully - it's visuals obscured by a constant miasma of dust.
The thing that won me over with this game was it's humanity.
It's a touching story, with fun climing, fun stealth, and interesting interactions with NPC's.
It doesn't pull any punches with it's content, and it gives a brutally honest opinion of what it would be like in a post apocolyptic world.
If there's one drawback for this game, it is its length. You'll easily blow through the game with it having around about 10 hours gametime, give or take, if you're trying to complete it all on normal difficulty.
It also feels like it should have gone further, and done more. Like it should have been bigger, with epic moment scattered throughout it. However, when I thought back on this, anything bigger with epic moments scattered through would have robbed the game of its humanity.

I recommend this if it's on sale, or for its full retail price if you're bored and want to play something with a bit of charm.

reviewText:
Wow. As far as I'm concerned, this game is severely underrated. Get it.

Yes, it does have bits and pieces I don't like - the entire world is grey-brown-depressing, but then again, this is about a global apocalyptic event that destroyed the world as we knew it. I found myself looking up to the (red) health bar from time to time for a contrast, however.

But it is surprisingly well-done. The music is good, and while the circumstances of The Event" are never detailed
date: the repercussions are. Society has vanished and mankind is showing just how little it takes for everything  to deteriorate further. There's a shortage of everything - you feel like kissing every bullet before firing it at someone. Luckily (but a little late in the game) you will also find a hunting bow
recommended: with its arrows being re-usable.\n\nThe only thing I don't really like is the ending
hoursPlayed: but for the sake of this being a recommendation
voteText: I won't spoil it for anyone. It is by no means a bad ending
helpfulPercent: just leaves me wanting more."

reviewText:
Feels like an interactive movie, not only in terms of ambience but also in terms of moral decisions.
The game is based on 3 major concepts:
A)  Carefully manage your human constitution and dexterity. I Am Alive does its best to constantly remind you that you  are human and fragile. A realistic moving/climbing system alongside a revolutionary psycological combat system play their part in this as well.
B) Explore. But do so with consequences. You might find something of use or you might use all your supplies for nothing.
C) Help others in need, however make sure that helping them doesn't jeopardise your own survival. Moral decisions are often in I Am Alive and the game does not really reward you for the right choice. There is no right choice and the only reward comes from your own morality and mentality of living.
If you are a fan of I Am Legend, but you are too old for mindless zombie killing then this is the title for you.

Yes, it does have bits and pieces I don't like - the entire world is grey-brown-depressing, but then again, this is about a global apocalyptic event that destroyed the world as we knew it. I found myself looking up to the (red) health bar from time to time for a contrast, however.

But it is surprisingly well-done. The music is good, and while the circumstances of The Event" are never detailed
date: the repercussions are. Society has vanished and mankind is showing just how little it takes for everything  to deteriorate further. There's a shortage of everything - you feel like kissing every bullet before firing it at someone. Luckily (but a little late in the game) you will also find a hunting bow
recommended: with its arrows being re-usable.\n\nThe only thing I don't really like is the ending
hoursPlayed: but for the sake of this being a recommendation
voteText: I won't spoil it for anyone. It is by no means a bad ending
helpfulPercent: just leaves me wanting more."
votesHelpful: November 2, 2012
votesTotal: true

reviewText:
Feels like an interactive movie, not only in terms of ambience but also in terms of moral decisions.
The game is based on 3 major concepts:
A)  Carefully manage your human constitution and dexterity. I Am Alive does its best to constantly remind you that you  are human and fragile. A realistic moving/climbing system alongside a revolutionary psycological combat system play their part in this as well.
B) Explore. But do so with consequences. You might find something of use or you might use all your supplies for nothing.
C) Help others in need, however make sure that helping them doesn't jeopardise your own survival. Moral decisions are often in I Am Alive and the game does not really reward you for the right choice. There is no right choice and the only reward comes from your own morality and mentality of living.
If you are a fan of I Am Legend, but you are too old for mindless zombie killing then this is the title for you.

It's a pretty good game with good visuals and a great story.. It's only downside is the horrid controls.
You often need to button mash the MOUSE button, and it doesn't seem to work quite well at times.
It shows that this game was originally a console game, and it really shouldn't have been ported to PC.
Despite that, the game is quite cheap, and for it's price, I'm definitely overlooking the faulty controls.

reviewText: A survival game done right. Can only use what you scavenge, ammo is rare, a very punishing stamina system. A very intense game with some very cool features such as stamina limited climbing, and the abillity to negogiate/bluff enemies, scare them away or into surrender with an empty gun, accidentally fire it however and they will hear it and pounce you. Very fun little game, can be played full survivor or in easier modes, even in normal mode, still retains atmosphere and intensity. Can be picked up for around 6-7 dollars, 6 hours gameplay, you can not go wrong.\nDo it.

reviewText:
I Am Alive is a bleak, depressing game. This doesn't make it a bad game. In fact, I think the atmosphere is quite good. In terms of the game itself the story is quite simple. A catostrohpic event happened while you were out of town. It has taken you a year to get back to your town and you are now trying to find your wife and child. On your quest to do this, you become connected with another family and you complete missions for them.

The game is brutally hard even when not on the hardest difficulty. You have scare resources and you have a stamina meter that prevents you from climbing or running forever. Also, saving the game only happens at random, spread-out times that are not controlled by the gamer. I imagine this is one of the main reason the game got beat up by critics.

Overall, I loved it even though it was completely bleak.

reviewText: Think Tomb Raider only with a male protagonist set in a post-apocaplyptic world.   The main character is a hero in a decidedly non-heroic world.  Gameplay alternates between climbing/exploration and combat.\n\nClimbing/exploration is tomb-raider like, although a little more on-rails in that if the game doesn't want you jumping, you won't be able to jump.  The second difference is a stamina meter which drops the longer your are climbing.  If it depletes, you fall to your death.  I liked this approach, although the scary" music that starts playing when you are at 75% or lower stamina starts to get irritating.  I enjoyed the climbing aspect of the game

reviewText:
DO NOT BUY
This is the worst survival game I have ever played. Where do I even start...

Bad controls. For example, you run using a left mouse button! The left mouse button! Yes, you can change key bindings but the same button is used for shooting, so you either have both running and shooting on LMB or none of them.
And this is even better: You can jump and climb only on specific spots where the developer allowed you to. Forget basic logic - you can climb this truck but not the same truck over there. You can grab this ledge but not that one. This turns the game into a guessing game. Guess where's the path the level designed made for you, because you can't go anywhere else!

The savepoint system. There is only one hard savepoint at the beginning of each chapter. So if you leave the game too soon or the game crashes (happened multiple times to me), be prepared to replay last 20-30 minutes.
There are also more soft checkpoints that you can use to spawn after death but the devs had another great idea - let's severely limit the number of respawns and if you spend them all, replay the whole chapter! Isn't it a great idea in a trial&error game where you can hardly predict or plan anything during your first playthrough? Splendid! Thankfully, the easy mode has unlimited respawns.
The savepoint system has one other major catch. It also your saves your stamina capacity, health and ammo. And this brings the last tiny" problem with...

The stamina system. This is the thing that made me quit the game for good. I'm fine with a stamina bar that you need to recharge by resting a bit. But here
date: if you spend all stamina points (which is often unavoidable in this game) you maximum stamina capacity starts to decrease. And the capacity doesn't recover by itself
recommended: you need to use very rare consumables to get the full stamina back.\nSo it's pretty easy to end up on a savepoint with only 20 % stamina bar
hoursPlayed: no consumables
voteText: and a long climbing sequence or a dust storm ahead. At this point your're done because it's impossible to continue
helpfulPercent: you die or fall almost immediately. Restarting the checkpoint doesn't help because it doesn't restore the stamina bar. And in my case the checkpoint was also a chapter savepoint so restarting the last chapter didn't help either. My only choices were either to restart the previous chapter and replay everything again (risking the same problem in the end)
votesHelpful: or to delete this piece of ♥♥♥♥ from my computer.\nI chose the latter."

reviewText: Every time I see this game in my library, I'm ashamed I payed money for it. Unless you enjoy excessively long and redundant climbing puzzles that are incredibly slow and boring, this game is not for you. Combat usually consists of... 1) See enemy. 2) Shoot enemy with gun. 3) engage in quick time event to kill the other enemies, mashing the same button over and over, hoping one of the other enemies doesn't decide they want to attack you while you are stuck in a QTE (Quick time event). ALL combat aside from firearms and sneak kills are QTEs.The exploration might be fun, if not for the blurred graphics to try to make it look better. The textures didn't look nice, so they just blurred everything. Oh yeah, the game has next to no color, so everything looks pretty similar. Movement is really clunky and the climbing is obnoxiously slow and unneccesary. Oh yeah, if you are having trouble with a section, the game will make it harder by lowering your max stamina. So in an exploration game, they discourage exploring while climbing so you don't get an obnoxious lessened max stamina, make everything look incredibly boring, and make the occasional encounter pretty underwhelming too. Ever get that feeling where you get an objective in a game and it becomes and irritation and a chore? That's basically this entire game. (Most of the exploration I found was just someone telling you to backtrack to somewhere you have already been. /:) I was incredibly disapointed by this game.

reviewText: I Am Alive is an atmospheric apocalyptic survivor game shown from a third person perspective.  The visuals and music are haunting and the the voice acting compliments the eery mood well.  Unfortunately the game shipped in a broken state and shockingly the xbox 360 controller for PC does not work and there is no workaround short of using a third party program to map through your keyboard.  This is shameful especially considering the game is a port.  It's sad that a large publisher like Ubisoft would not rush to fix such a major bug.  Someday I Am Alive might be worth the price, but as it stands I recommend gamers stay away from this broken product.
